sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What was't?

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Faith, to put his Play into Rithme; for Rithme, you know, often makes mystical Nonsence pass with the Criticks for Wit, and a double meaning saying with the Ladies, for soft, tender, and moving passion. But, now I talk of passion, I saw your old Lover this morning— Captain—

div.stage: Enter Captain Manly, Freeman and Fidelia standing behind.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Whom?— nay, you need not whisper.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We are luckily got hither unobserv'd:— How! in a close conversation with these supple Rascals, the Out-casts of Sempstresses shops?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Faith, pardon her, Captain, that, since she cou'd no longer be entertain'd with your manly bluntness, and honest love, she takes up with the pert chat and common place flattery of these fluttering Parrots of the Town, Apes and Echoes of Men only.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Do not you, Sir, play the Echo too, mock me, dally with my own words, and shew your self as impertinent as they are.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, Captain—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nay, Lieutenant, do not excuse her, methinks she looks very kindly upon 'em both, and seems to be pleas'd with what that Fool there sayes to her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You lye, Sir, and hold your peace, that I may not be provok'd to give you a worse reply.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Manly return'd, d'ye say! And is he safe?

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: My Lord saw him too. Heark you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She yet seems concern'd for my safety, and perhaps they are admitted now here but for their news of me; for Intelligence indeed is the common Passport of nauseous Fools, when they go their round of good Tables and Houses.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I heard of his fighting only, without particulars, and confess I alwayes lov'd his Brutal courage, because it made me hope it might rid me of his more Brutal love.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: But is he at last return'd, d'ye say, unhurt?

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Ay faith, without doing his business; for the Rogue has been these two years pretending to a wooden Leg, which he wou'd take from Fortune, as kindly, as the Staff of a Marshal of France, and rather read his name in a Gazet—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Than in the Entail of a good Estate.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So!—

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: I have an Ambition, I must confess, of losing my heart, before such a fair Enemy as your self, Madam; but that silly Rogues shou'd be ambitious of losing their Arms, and—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Looking like a pair of Compasses.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: But he has no use of his Arms, but to set 'em on Kimbow, for he never pulls off his Hat, at least not to me, I'm sure; for you must know, Madam, he has a fanatical hatred to good company: he can't abide me.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: O, be not so severe to him, as to say he hates good company; for I assure you he has a great respect, esteem and kindness for me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That kind, civil Rogue has spoken yet ten thousand times worse of me, than t'other.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Well, if he be return'd, Mr. Novel, then shall I be pester'd again with his boistrous Sea-love; have my Alcove smell like a Cabin, my Chamber perfum'd with his Tarpaulin Brandenburgh, and hear vollies of Brandy sighs, enough to make a Fog in ones Room. Eoh! I hate a Lover that smells like Thames-street!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I can bear no longer, and need hear no more. [Aside. But, since you have these two Pulvillio Boxes, these Essence Bottles, this pair of Musk-Cats here, I hope I may venture to come yet nearer you.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Overheard us then?

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: I hope he heard me not.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Most noble and heroick Captain, your most oblig'd, faithful, humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Dear Tar, thy humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Away— Madam

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Nay, I think I have fitted you for listning.

div.stage: [Thrusts Novel and Plausible on each side.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You have fitted me, for believing you cou'd not be fickle, tho' you were young; cou'd not dissemble Love, tho'twas your interest; nor be in vain, tho' you were handsom; nor break your promise, tho' to a parting Lover; nor abuse your best Friend, tho' you had Wit: but I take not your contempt of me worse, than your esteem, or civility for these things here, tho' you know 'em.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Things!

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Let the Captain Railly a little.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, things: canst thou be angry, thou thing?

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: No, since my Lord sayes you speak in Raillery; for, tho' your Sea-raillery be something rough, yet I confess we use one another to as bad every day, at Lockets, and never quarrel for the matter.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Nay, noble Captain, be not angry with him: A word with you, I beseech you.—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Well, we Women, like the rest of the Cheats of the World, when our Cullies or Creditors have found us out, and will, or can trust no longer; pay Debts, and satisfie Obligations, with a quarrel, the kindest Present a Man can make to his Mistress, when he can make no more Presents: for oftentimes in Love, as at Cards, we are forc'd to play foul, only to give over the game; and use our Lovers, like the Cards, when we can get no more by 'em, throw 'em up in a pet, upon the first dispute.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: My Lord, all that you have made me know by your whispering, which I knew not before, is, that you have a stinking breath: there's a secret, for your secret.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Pshaw! pshaw!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But, Madam, tell me, pray, what was't, about this spark, cou'd take you? was it the merit of his fashionable impudence, the briskness of his noise, the wit of his laugh, his judgment, or fancy in his garniture? or was it a well-trim'd Glove, or the scent of it that charm'd you?

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, 'gad these Sea-Captains make nothing of dressing: but let me tell you, Sir, a man by his dress, as much as by any thing, shews his wit and judgment, nay, and his courage too.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: How his courage, Mr. Novel?

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Why, for example, by red Breeches, tuck'd up Hair or Perruke, a greasie broad Belt, and now adayes a short Sword.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Thy courage will appear more by thy Belt than thy Sword, I dare swear. Then, Madam, for this gentle piece of courtesie, this Man of tame honour, what cou'd you find in him? was it his languishing affected
tone? his mannerly look? his second-hand flattery, the refuse of the Play house tiring-rooms? or his slavish obsequiousness, in watching at the door of your Box at the Play-house, for your hand to your Chair? or his janty way of playing with your Fan? or was it the Gunpowder spot on his hand, or the Jewel in his ear, that purchas'd your heart?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Good jealous Captain, no more of your—

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: No, let him go on, Madam, for perhaps he may make you laugh: and I wou'd contribute to your pleasure any way.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Gentle Rogue!

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: No, noble Captain, you cannot sure think any thing cou'd take me more than that heroick Title of yours, Captain; for you know we Women love honour inordinately.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Hah, ha, faith she is with thee, Bully, for thy Raillery.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Faith so shall I be with you, no Bully, for your grinning.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Then, that noble Lyon-like meen of yours, that Soldier-like weather beaten complexion, and that manly roughness of your voice; how can they otherwise than charm us Women, who hate Effeminacy!

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Hah, ha! faith I can't hold from laughing.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nor shall I from kicking anon.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: And then, that Captain-like carelesness in your dress, but especially your Scarf; 'twas just such another, only a little higher ty'd, made me in love with my Taylor, as he past by my Window the last Training day; for we Women adore a Martial Man, and you have nothing wanting to make you more one, or more agreeable, but a wooden Leg.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Nay, i'faith there your Ladyship was a Wag, and it was fine, just, and well Railly'd.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Madam, with you Ladies too, Martial Men must needs be very killing.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Peace, you Bartholomew-Fair Buffoons; and be not you vain that these laugh on your side, for they will laugh at their own dull jests: but no more of 'em, for I will only suffer now this Lady to be witty and merry.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: You wou'd not have your Panegyrick interrupted. I go on then to your humor. Is there any thing more agreeable, than the pretty sullenness of that? than the greatness of your courage? which most of all appears in your spirit of contradiction, for you dare give all Mankind the Lye; and your Opinion is your onely Mistress, for you renounce that too, when it becomes another Mans.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Hah, ha! I cannot hold, I must laugh at thee Tar, faith!

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: And i'faith, dear Captain, I beg your pardon, and leave to laugh at you too, tho' I protest I mean you no hurt; but, when a Lady Raillies, a stander by must be complaisant, and do her reason in laughing: Hah, ha.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Why, you impudent, pitiful Wretches, you presume sure upon
your Effeminacy to urge me; for you are in all things so like Women, that you may think it in me a kind of Cowardice to beat you.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: No Hectoring, good Captain.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Or, perhaps, you think this Ladies presence secures you; but have a care, she has talk'd her self out of all the respect I had for her; and by using me ill before you, has given me a priviledge of using you so before her: but if you wou'd preserve your respect to her, and not be beaten before her, go, be gone immediately.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Be gone! what?

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Nay, worthy, noble, generous Captain.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Be gone, I say.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Be gone again! to us be gone!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No chattering, Baboons, instantly be gone. Or—

div.stage: [Manly puts 'em out of the Room: Novel struts, Plausible cringes.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Well, Madam, we'll go make the Cards ready in your Bed-chamber; sure you will not stay long with him.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Turn hither your rage, good Captain Swagger-huff, and be saucy with your Mistress, like a true Captain; but be civil to your Rivals and Betters, and do not threaten any thing but me here; no, not so much as my Windows, nor do not think your self in the Lodgings of one of your Suburb Mistresses beyond the Tower.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Do not give me cause to think so, for those less infamous Women part with their Lovers, just as you did from me, with unforc'd vows of constancy, and floods of willing tears; but the same winds bear away their Lovers, and their vows: And for their grief, if the credulous unexpected Fools return, they find new Comforters, fresh Cullies, such as I found here. The mercenary love of those Women too suffer shipwrack, with their Gallants fortunes; now you have heard Chance has us'd me scurvily, therefore you do too. Well, persevere in your ingratitude, falshood, and disdain; have constancy in something, and I promise you to be as just to your real scorn, as I was to your feign'd love: And henceforward will despise, contemn, hate, loath, and detest you, most faithfully.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Get the Hombre Cards ready in the next Room, Lettice, and—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Bravely resolv'd, Captain.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And you'll be sure to, keep your word, I hope, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I hope so too.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Do you but hope it, Sir? if you are not as good as your word, 'twill be the first time you ever brag'd sure.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She has restor'd my reason with my heart.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
But, now you talk of restoring Captain, there are other things
which, next to one's heart, one wou'd not part with; I mean your Jewels and Money, which it seems she has, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What's that to you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Pardon me, whatsoever is yours, I have a share in't, I'm sure, which I will not lose for asking, tho' you may be too generous, or too angry now to do't your self.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nay, then I'll make bold to make my claim too.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Hold, you impertinent, officious Fops— How have I been deceiv'd!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Madam, there are certain Appurtenances to a Lover's heart, call'd Jewels, which alwayes go along with it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And which, with Lovers, have no value in themselves, but from the heart they come with; our Captain's, Madam, it seems you scorn to keep, and much more will those worthless things without it, I am confident.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: A Gentleman, so well made as you are, may be confident— us easie Women cou'd not deny you any thing you ask, if 'twere for your self; but, since 'tis for another, I beg your leave to give him my Answer. (An agreeable young Fellow this!— And wou'd not be my Aversion!) [Aside.] Captain, your young Friend here has a very persuading Face, I confess; yet you might have ask'd me your self, for those Trifles you left with me, which (heark you a little, for I dare trust you with the secret: you are a Man of so much Honour I'm sure;) I say then, not expecting your return, or hoping ever to see you again, I have deliver'd your Jewels to—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: My Husband.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your Husband!

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Ay, my Husband; for, since you cou'd leave me, I am lately, and privately marry'd to one, who is a Man of so much Honour and Experience in the World, that I dare not ask him for your Jewels again, to restore 'em to you; lest he shou'd conclude you never wou'd have parted with 'em to me, on any other score, but the exchange of my Honour: which rather than you'd let me lose, you'd lose I'm sure you self, those Trifles of yours.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Triumphant Impudence! but marry'd too!

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: O, speak not so loud, my Servants know it not: I am marry'd; there's no resisting one's Destiny, or Love, you know.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why, did you love him too?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Most passionately; nay, love him now, tho' I have marry'd him, and he me: which mutual love, I hope you are too good, too generous a Man to disturb, by any future claim, or visits to me. 'Tis true, he is now absent in the Countrey, but returns shortly; therefore I beg of you, for your own ease and quiet, and my Honour, you will never see me more.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I wish I never had seen you.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: But if you shou'd ever have any thing to say to me hereafter, let that young Gentleman there, be your Messenger.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You wou'd be kinder to him: I find he shou'd be welcome.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Alas, his Youth wou'd keep my Husband from suspicions, and his visits from scandal; for we Women may have pity for such as he, but no love: And I already think you do not well to spirit him away to Sea; and the Sea is already but too rich with the spoils of the shore.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: True perfect Woman!— If I cou'd say any thing more injurious to her now, I wou'd; for I cou'd out-rail a bilk'd Whore, or a kick'd Coward: but, now I think on't, that were rather to discover my love, than hatred; and I must not talk, for something I must do.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I think I have given him enough of me now, never to be troubled with him again.— [Aside. Enter Lettice. Well, Lettice, are the Cards and all ready within? I come then Captain, I beg your pardon: You will not make one at Hombre?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, Madam, but I'll wish you a little good luck before you go.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: No, if you wou'd have me thrive, Curse me; for that you'll do heartily, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Then, if you will have it so, May all the Curses light upon you, Women ought to fear, and you deserve; first may the Curse of loving Play attend your sordid Covetousness, and Fortune cheat you, by trusting to her, as you have cheated me; the Curse of Pride, or a good Reputation, fall on your Lust; the Curse of Affectation on your Beauty; the Curse of your Husbands company on your Pleasures; and the Curse of your Gallant's disappointments in his absence; and the Curse of scorn, jealousie, or despair, on your love: and then the Curse of loving on.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: And, to requite all your Curses, I will only return you your last; May the Curse of loving me still, fall upon your proud hard heart, that cou'd be so cruel to me in these horrid Curses: but Heaven forgive you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Hell, and the Devil, reward thee.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well, you see now, Mistresses, like Friends, are lost, by letting 'em handle your Money; and most Women are such kind of Witches, who can have no power over a Man, unless you give 'em Money; but when once they have got any from you, they never leave you, till they have all: therefore I never dare give a Woman a farthing.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Well, there is yet this comfort by losing one's Money with one's Mistress, a Man is out of danger of getting another; of being made prize again by love; who, like a Pyrat, takes you by spreading false Colours:
but when once you have run your Ship aground, the treacherous Picaroon looss, so by your ruine you save your self from slavery at least.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Mrs. Lettice, here's Madam Blackacre come to wait upon her Honour.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: D'ye hear that? let us be gone, before she comes; for hence forward I'll avoid the whole damn'd Sex for ever, and Woman as a sinking Ship.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And I'll stay, to revenge on her your quarrel to the Sex; for out of love to her Jointure, and hatred to business, I wou'd marry her, to make an end of her thousand Suits, and my thousand engagements, to the comfort of two unfortunate sorts of people; my Plaintiffs, and her Defendants; my Creditors, and her Adversaries.

div.stage: Enter Widow Blackacre led in by Major Oldfox, and Jerry Blackacre following, laden with green Bags.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: 'Tis an arrant Sea-Ruffian, but I am glad I met with him at last, to serve him again, Major, for the last service was not good in Law. Boy, Duck, Ierry, where is my Paper of Memorandums? give me Child: so. Where is my Cousin Olivia, now, my kind Relation?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Here is one that wou'd be your kind Relation, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why, faith (to be short) to marry you, Widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Is not this the wild rude person we saw at Captain Manly's?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Ay, forsooth, an't please.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What wou'd you? what are you? Marry me!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay faith, for I am a younger Brother, and you are a Widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are an impertinent person, and go about your business.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I have none, but to marry thee, Widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But I have other business, I'd have you to know.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But you have no business anights, Widow; and I'll make you pleasanter business than any you have: for anights, I assure you, I am a Man of great business; for the business—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go, I'm sure you're an idle Fellow.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Try me but, Widow, and employ me as you find my abilities, and industry.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Pray be civil to the Lady, Mr.— she's a person of quality, a person that is no person—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes, but she's a person that is a Widow: be you mannerly to her, because you are to pretend only to be her Squire, to arm her to her Lawyers Chambers; but I will be impudent and baudy, for she must love and marry me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Marry come up, you saucy familiar Iack! You think with us Widows, 'tis no more than up, and ride. Gad forgive me, now adayes, every idle, young, hectoring, roaring Companion, with a pair of turn'd red Breeches, and a broad Back, thinks to carry away any Widow, of the best degree; but I'd have you to know, Sir, all Widows are not got, like places at Court, by Impudence and Importunity only.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: No, no, soft, soft, you are a young Man, and not fit—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: For a Widow? Yes sure, old Man, the fitter.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Go to, go to, if others had not laid in their claims before you—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Not you, I hope.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Why not I, Sir? Sure I am a much more proportionable match for her, than you, Sir; I, who am an elder Brother, of a comfortable Fortune, and of equal Years with her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How's that? You unmannerly person, I'm have you to know, I was born but in Ann' undec' Caroli prim'.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Your pardon, Lady, your pardon; be not offended with your very Servant.— But I say, Sir, you are a beggarly younger Brother, twenty Years younger than her; without any Land or Stock, but your great stock of Impudence: therefore what pretension can you have to her?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You have made it for me; first, because I am a younger Brother.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, is that a sufficient Plea to a Relict? How appears it, Sir? by what foolish custom?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: By custom, time out of mind only. Then, Sir, because I have nothing to keep me after her death, I am the likelier to take care of her life. And, for my being twenty Years younger than her, and having a sufficient stock of Impudence, I leave it to her whether they will be valid exceptions to me, in her Widow's Law or Equity.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Well, she has been so long in Chancery, that I'll stand to her Equity and Decree between us. Come, Lady, pray snap up this young Snap at first, or we shall be troubled with him; give him a City Widow's Answer: (that is, with all the ill breeding imaginable.) [Aside to the Wid. Come, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well then, to make an end of this foolish Wooing, for nothing interrupts business more; first, for you, Major—

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: You declare in my favour then?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What direct the Court? (Come, young Lawyer, thou sha't be a Counsel for me.)

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Gad, I shall betray your Cause then, as well as an older Lawyer, never stir

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: First, I say, for you Major, my walking Hospital of an ancient Foundation, thou Bag of Mummy, that wou'dst fall asunder, if 'twere not for thy Cere-cloaths—

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: How, Lady?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Hah, ha—

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Hey, brave Mother! use all Suitors thus, for my sake.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Thou wither'd, hobling, distorted Cripple; nay, thou art Cripple all over; wou'dst thou make me the Staff of thy Age, the Crutch of thy Decrepidness? Me—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well said Widow! faith, thou wou'dst make a Man love thee now, without dissembling.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Thou sensless, impertinent, quibling, driveling, feeble, paralytic, impotent, sumbling, frigid Nicompoop.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Hey, brave Mother, for calling of names, ifac!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Wou'dst thou make a Caudlemaker, a Nurse of me? Can't you be Bed-rid, without a Bed-fellow? Won't your Swan-skins Furrs, Flannels, and the scorch'd Trencher keep you warm there? Wou'd you have me your Scotch-warming Pan, with a Pox to you? Me!—

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: O Heav'ns!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I told you I shou'd be thought the fitter Man, Major.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Ay, you old Fobus, and you wou'd have been my Guardian, wou'd you? to have taken care of my Estate, that half of't shou'd never come to me, by letting long Leases at Pepper-corn Rents.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If I wou'd have marry'd an old Man, 'tis well known I might have marry'd an Earl; nay, what's more, a Judge, and been cover'd the Winter-nights with the Lamb-skins, which I prefer to the Ermins of Nobles: And dost thou think I wou'd wrong my poor Minor there, for you?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Your Minor is a chopping Minor, God bless him.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Your Minor may be a Major of Horse or Foot, for his bigness; and, it seems, you will have the cheating of your Minor to your self.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, bear Witness; Cheat my Minor! I'll bring my Action of the Case for the slander.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, I wou'd bear false Witness for thee now, Widow, since you have done me justice, and have thought me the fitter Man for you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fair, and softly Sir, 'tis my Minor's Case, more than my own: And I must do him justice now on you.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: So then.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are first, (I warrant) some Renegado from the Inns of Court, and the Law; and thou'lt come to suffer for't, by the Law: that is, be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Not about your neck, forsooth, I hope.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But, Madam—

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Hear the Court.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Thou art some debauch'd, drunken, leud, hectoring, gaming Companion, and want'st some Widow's old Gold to nick upon; but, I thank you, Sir, that's for my Lawyers.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Faith, we shou'd ne'r quarrel about that; for Guineys wou'd serve my turn: but, Widow—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Thou art a foul-mouth'd Boaster of thy Lust, a meer Bragadochio of thy strength for Wine and Women, and wilt belie thy self more than thou dost Women, and art every way a base deceiver of Women: And wou'd deceive me too, wou'd you?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay faith, Widow, this is Judging without seeing the Evidence.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I say, you are a worn-out Whoremaster, at five and twenty both in Body and Fortune: And cannot be trusted by the common Wenches of the Town, lest you shou'd not pay 'em; nor by the Wives of the Town, lest you shou'd pay 'em: so you want Women, and wou'd have me your Baud, to procure 'em for you.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Faith, if you had any good Acquaintance, Widow, 'twou'd be civilly done of thee; for I am just come from Sea.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I mean, you wou'd have me keep you, that you might turn Keeper; for poor Widows are only us'd like Bauds by you; you go to Church with us, but to get other Women to lie with. In fine, you are a cheating, chousing Spendthrift: And, having sold your own Annuity, wou'd waste my Jointure.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: And make havock of our Estate personal, and all our old gilt Plate; I shou'd soon be picking up all our mortgag'd Apostle-Spoons, Bowls and Beakers, out of most of the Ale-houses, betwixt Hercules Pillars and the Boatswain in Wapping: nay, and you'd be scouring amongst my Trees, and make 'em knock down one another, like routed reeling Watchmen at midnight. Wou'd you so, Bully?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, pr'ythee, Widow, hear me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, Sir, I'd have you to know, thou pitiful, paltry, lath-back'd Fellow, if I wou'd have marry'd a young Man, 'tis well known, I cou'd have had any young Heir in Norfolk; nay, the hopefull'st young Man this day at the Kings-Bench Bar; I that am a Relict and Executrix of known plentiful Assits and Parts, who understand my self and the Law: And wou'd you have me under Covert Baron again? No, Sir, no Covert Baron for me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But, dear Widow, hear me. I value you only, not your Jointure.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, hold there, I know your love to a Widow, is covetousness of her Jointure: And a Widow, a little stricken in Years, with a good Jointure, is like an old Mansion-house in a good Purchase, never valu'd; but take one, take t'other: And perhaps, when you are in possession, you'd neglect it, let it drop to the ground, for want of necessary repairs, or expences upon't.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No, Widow, one wou'd be sure to keep all tight, when one is to forfeit one's Lease by dilapidation.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie, fie, I neglect my Business, with this foolish discourse of love. Ierry, Child, let me see the List of the Jury: I'm sure my Cousin Olivia has some Relations amongst 'em. But where is she?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, Widow, but hear me one word only.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, no more, pray; I will no more hearken again to your foolish Love motions, than to offers of Arbitration.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well, I'll follow thee yet; for he that has a pretension at Court, or to a Widow, must never give over for a little ill usage.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Therefore I'll get her by Assiduity, Patience, and Long-sufferings, which you will not undergo; for you idle young Fellows leave off Love, when it comes to be Business; and Industry gets more Women, than Love.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, Industry, the Fool's and old Man's merit; but I'll be industrious too, and make a business on't, and get her by Law, Wrangling, and Contests, and not by Sufferings: And, because you are no dangerous Rival, I'll give thee counsel, Major.

lg.l: If you Litigious Widow e'r wou'd gain,
Sigh not to her; but by the Law complain:
To her, as to a Baud, Defendant Sue
With Statutes, and make Iustice Pimp for you.

div.head: ACT. III. Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter Manly and Freeman, two Sailors behind.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I Hate this place, worse than a Man that has inherited a Chancery Suit: I wish I were well out on't again.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why, you need not be afraid of this place: for a Man without Money, needs no more fear a croud of Lawyers, than a croud of Pick-pockets.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: This, the Reverend of the Law wou'd have thought the Palace or Residence of Justice; but, if it be, she lives here with the State of a Turkish Emperor, rarely seen; and besieg'd, rather than defended, by her numerous black Guard here.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Methinks, 'tis like one of their own Halls, in Christmas time, whither, from all parts, Fools bring their Money, to try, by the Dice, (not the worst Judges) whether it shall be their own, or no: but, after a tedious fretting and wrangling, they drop away all their Money, on both sides; and finding neither the better, at last, go emptily and lovingly away together, to the Tavern, joining their Curses against the young Lawyers Box, that sweeps all, like the old ones.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Spoken, like a Revelling Christmas Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes, I was one, I confess; but was fain to leave the Law, out of Conscience, and fall to making false Musters; rather chose to Cheat the King, than his Subjects; Plunder, rather than take Fees.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Well, a Plague, and a Purse Famine, light on the Law; and that Female limb of it, who drag'd me hither to day: but pr'ythee go see if, in that croud of dagled Gowns there, thou canst find her.
sp.stage: [Pointing to a croud of Lawyers, at the end of the Stage.
sp.l: How hard it is to be an Hypocrite!
At least to me, who am but newly so.
I thought it once a kind of Knavery,
Nay, Cowardice, to hide ones faults; but now
The common frailty, Love, becomes my shame.
He must not know I love th' ungrateful still,
Lest he contemn me, more than she: for I,
It seems, can undergo a Womans scorn,
But not a Mans—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Sir, good Sir, generous Captain.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Pr'ythee, kind Impertinence, leave me. Why shou'dst thou follow me, flatter my Generosity now, since thou know'st I have no Money left? if I had it, I'd give it thee, to buy my quiet.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I never follow'd yet, Sir, Reward or Fame, but you alone; nor do I now beg any thing, but leave to share your miseries: You shou'd not be a Niggard of 'em, since, methinks, you have enough to spare. Let me follow you now, because you hate me, as you have often said.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I ever hated a Coward's company, I must confess.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Let me follow you, till I am none then; for you, I'm sure, will through such Worlds of dangers, that I shall be inur'd to 'em; nay, I shall be afraid of your anger more than danger, and so turn valiant out of fear. Dear Captain, do not cast me off, till you have try'd me once more: do not, do not go to Sea again without me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thou to Sea! to Court, thou Fool; remember the advice I gave thee: thou art a handsom Spaniel, and canst faun naturally; go, busk about, and run thy self into the next great Man's Lobby: first faun upon the Slaves without, and then run into the Ladies Bed-chamber; thou may'st be admitted, at last, to tumble her Bed: go, seek, I say, and lose me; for I am not able to keep thee: I have not Bread for my self.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Therefore I will not go, because then I may help and serve you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thou!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir; for, at worst, I cou'd beg or steal for you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay, more bragging! dost thou not know there's venturing your life, in stealing? Go, pr'ythee, away: thou art as hard to shake off, as that flattering effeminating mischief, Love.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Love, did you name? Why, you are not so miserable as to be yet in Love, sure!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
No no, pr'ythee away, be gone, or— I had almost discover'd my Love and Shame; well, if I had? that thing cou'd not think the worse of me:— or if he did?— no— yes, he
shall know it— he shall— but then I must never leave him, for they are such secrets, that make Parasites and Pimps Lords of their Masters; for any slavery or tyranny is easier than Love's. [Aside. Come hither. Since thou art so forward to serve me, hast thou but resolution enough to endure the torture of a secret? for such, to some, is insupportable.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I wou'd keep it as safe, as if your dear precious life depended on't.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Dam your dearness. It concerns more than my life, my honour.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Doubt it not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And do not discover it, by too much fear of discovering it; but have a great care you let not Freeman find it out.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir. I am already all joy, with the hopes of your commands; and shall be all wings, in the execution of 'em: speak quickly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You said you wou'd beg for me.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Then you shall beg for me.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That is, Pimp for me.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: D'ye start! thinkst thou, thou cou'dst do me any other service? Come, no dissembling honour: I know you can do it handsomly, thou were made for't: You have lost your time with me at Sea, you must recover it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Do not, Sir, beget your self more Reasons for your Aversion to me, and make my obedience to you a fault: I am the unfittest in the World, to do you such a service.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your cunning arguing against it, shews but how sit you are for it. No more dissembling: here, (I say) you must go use it for me, to Olivia.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: To her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Go flatter, lie, kneel, promise, any thing to get her for me: I cannot live, unless I have her. Didst thou not say thou wou'dst do any thing, to save my life? And she said you had a persuading face.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: But, did not you say, Sir, your honour was dearer to you, than your life? And wou'd you have me contribute to the loss of that, and carry love from you, to the most infamous, most false, and—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And most beautifull—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Most ungrateful Woman, that ever liv'd; for sure she must be so, that cou'd desert you so soon, use you so basely, and so lately too: do not, do not forget it, Sir, and think—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, I will not forget it, but think of revenge: I will lie with her, out of revenge. Go, be gone, and prevail for me, or never see me more.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: You scorn'd her last night.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I know not what I did last night; I dissembled last night.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Heavens!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Be gone, I say, and bring me love or compliance back, or hopes at least, or I'll never see thy face again: by—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: O do not swear, Sir, first hear me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am impatient, away, you'll find me here till twelve.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Not one word, no insinuating Argument more, or soothing persuasion; you'll have need of all your Rhetorick with her: go, strive to alter her, not me; be gone.

div.stage: [Ex. Man. at the end of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Shou'd I discover to him now my Sex,
And lay before him his strange cruelty,
Twou'd but incense it more.— No, 'tis not time.
For his Love, must I then betray my own?
Were ever Love or Chance, till now, severe?
Or shifting Woman pos'd with such a task?
Forc'd to beg that which kills her, if obtain'd;
And give away her Lover not to lose him.

div.stage: Enter Widow Blackacre in the middle of half a dozen Lawyers, whisper'd to by a Fellow in black, Jerry Blackacre following the croud.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Offer me a Reference, you saucy Companion you! d'ye know who you speak to? Art thou a Solicitor in Chancery, and offer a Reference? A pretty Fellow! Mr. Serjeant Ploddon, here's a Fellow has the impudence to offer me a Reference.

sp.speaker: Serj. Plod.
sp.p: Who's that has the impudence to offer a Reference within these Walls?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, for a Splitter of Causes to do't!

sp.speaker: Serj. Plod.
sp.p: No, Madam, to a Lady learned in the Law, as you are, the offer of a Reference were to impose upon you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, no, never fear me for a Reference, Mr. Serjeant. But, come, have you not forgot your Brief? Are you sure you shan't make the mistake of— Hark you— [Whispers.] Go then, go to your Court of Common-Pleas, and say one thing over and over again: You do it so naturally, you'll never be suspected for protracting time.

sp.speaker: Serj. Plod.
sp.p: Come, I know the course of the Court, and your business.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Let's see, Ierry, where are my Minutes? Come, Mr. Quaint, pray go talk a great deal for me in Chancery; let your words be easie, and
your Sense hard, my Cause requires it: Branch it bravely, and deck my Cause with flowers, that the Snake may lie hidden Go, go, and be sure you remember the Decree of my Lord Chancellor Tricesimo quart ' of the Queen.

sp.speaker: Quaint.
sp.p: I will, as I see cause, extenuate, or examplifie Matter of Fact; baffle Truth, with Impudence; answer Exceptions, with Questions, tho' never so impertinent; for Reasons, give 'em Words; for Law and Equity, Tropes and Figures: And so relax and enervate the sinews of their Argument, with the oyl of my Eloquence. But when my Lungs can reason no longer, and not being able to say any thing more for our Cause, say every thing of our Adversary; whose Reputation, though never so clear and evident in the eye of the World, yet with sharp Invectives—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: (Alias Belin'sgate.)

sp.speaker: Quaint.
sp.p: With poinant and sowre Invectives, I say, I will deface, wipe out, and obliterate his fair Reputation, even as a Record with the juice of Lemons; and tell such a Story, (for, the truth on't is, all that we can do for our Client, in Chancery, is telling a Story) a fine Story, a long Story, such a Story.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Go, save thy breath for the Cause; talk at the Bar, Mr. Quaint: You are so copiously fluent, you can weary any ones ears, sooner than your own tongue. Go, weary our Adversaries Counsel, and the Court: Go, thou art a fine-spoken person: Adad, I shall make thy Wife jealous of me: if you can but court the Court into a Decree for us. Go, get you gone, and remember— [Whispers] [Exit Quaint. Come, Mr. Blunder, pray baul foundly for me, at the Kings-Bench; bluster, sputter, question, cavil; but be sure your Argument be intricate enough, to confound the Court: And then you do my business. Talk what you will, but be sure your tongue never stand still; for your own noise will secure your Sense from Censure: 'tis like coughing or heming when one has got the Belly-ake, which stifles the unmannerly noise. Go, dear Rogue, and succeed; and I'll invite thee, ere it be long, to more souz'd Venison.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, after your Verdict, your Judgment shall not be Arrested, upon if's and and's.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Petulant, let me give you some new instructions, for our Cause in the Exchequer: Are the Barons sate?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Yes, no; may be they are, may be they are not: what know I? what care I?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hey day! I wish you wou'd but snap up the Counsel on t'other side anon, at the Bar, as much; and have a little more patience with me, that I might instruct you a little better.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: You instruct me! What is my Brief for, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ay, but you seldom read your Brief, but at the Bar, if you do it then.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Perhaps I do, perhaps I don't, and perhaps 'tis time enough: pray hold your self contented, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, if you go there too, I will not be contented, Sir, tho' you, I see, will lose my Cause for want of speaking, I wo'not: You shall hear me, and shall be instructed. Let's see your Brief.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Send your Solicitor to me, instructed by a Woman! I'd have you to know, I do not wear a Bar-gown—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By a Woman! And I'd have you to know, I am no common Woman; but a Woman conversant in the Laws of the Land, as well as your self, tho' I have no Bar-gown.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Go to, go to, Mistress, you are impertinent, and there's your Brief for you: instruct me!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Impertinent to me, you saucy Iack you! You return my Breviate, but where's my Fee? You'll be sure to keep that, and scan that so well, that if there chance to be but a brass Half-crown in't, one's sure to hear on't again: wou'd you wou'd but look on your Breviate half so narrowly. But pray give me my Fee too, as well as my Brief.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Mistress, that's without Precedent. When did a Counsel ever return his Fee, pray? And you are impertinent, and ignorant, to demand it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Impertinent again, and ignorant to me! Gadsbodikins, you puny Upstart in the Law, to use me so, you Green Bag Carrier, you Murderer of unfortunate Causes, the Clerks Ink is scarce off of your fingers, you that newly come from Lamblacking the Judges shooes, and are not fit to wipe mine; you call me impertinent and ignorant! I wou'd give thee a Cuff on the ear, sitting the Courts, if I were ignorant. Marry gep, if it had not been for me, thou hadst been yet but a hearing Counsel at the Bar. [Ex. Petulant. Enter Mr. Buttongown, crossing the Stage in haste. Mr. Buttongown, Mr. Buttongown, whither so fast? what, won't you stay till we are heard?

sp.speaker: Butt.
sp.p: I cannot, Mrs. Blackacre, I must be at the Council, my Lord's Cause stays there for me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And mine suffers here.

sp.speaker: Butt.
sp.p: I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Butt.
sp.p: What's that to me?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Consider the five pound Fee, if not my Cause: that was something to you.

sp.speaker: Butt.
sp.p: Away, away, pray be not so troublesom, Mistress, I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Nay, but consider a little, I am your old Client, my Lord but a
new one; or, let him be what he will, he will hardly be a better Client to you, than my self: I hope you believe I shall be in Law as long as I live? therefore am no despicable Client. Well, but go to your Lord, I know you expect he shou'd make you a Judge one day; but I hope his promise to you will prove a true Lord's promise: But, that he might be sure to fail you, I wish you had his Bond for't.

sp.speaker: Butt.
sp.p: But what will you yet be thus impertinent, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech you, Sir, stay; if it be but to tell me my Lord's Case: come, in short.

sp.speaker: Butt.
sp.p: Nay, then—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well, Ierry, observe Child, and lay it up for hereafter: These are those Lawyers who, by being in all Causes, are in none; therefore if you wou'd have 'em for you, let your Adversary fee 'em; for he may chance to depend upon 'em: and so, in being against thee, they'll be for thee.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Ay, Mother, they put me in mind of the unconscionable Woers of Widows, who undertake briskly their Matrimonial business for their money; but when they have got it once, let who's will drudge for them; therefore have a care of 'em, forsooth: there's Advice for your Advice.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well said, Boy, come, Mr. Splitcause, pray go see when my Cause in Chancery comes on; and go speak with Mr. Quillet in the Kings-Bench, and Mr. Quirk in the Common-Pleas, and see how our matters go there.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Lady, a good and propitious morning to you; and may all your Causes go as well, as if I my self were Judge of 'em.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir, excuse me, I am busie, and cannot answer Complements in Westminster-hall. Go, Mr. Splitcause, and come to me again, to that Booksellers, there I'll stay for you, that you may be sure to find me.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: No, Sir, come to the other Booksellers, I'll attend your Ladiship thither.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why to the other?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Because he is my Bookseller, Lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What, to sell you Lozenges for your Catarrh? or Medicines for your Corns? what else can a Major deal with a Bookseller for?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Lady, he Prints for me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, are you an Author?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Of some few Essayes; deign you, Lady, to peruse 'em. (She is a Woman of parts, and I must win her by shewing mine.)

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Will you see Culpepper, Mistress? Aristotle's Problems? The Compleat Midwife?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, let's see Dalton, Hughs, Shepherd, Wingate.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: We have no Law-books.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No? You are a pretty Bookseller then.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Come, have you e're a one of my Essayes left?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, we have enough, and shall alwayes have 'em.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why, they are good, steady, lasting Ware.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Nay, I hope they will live, let's see. Be pleas'd, Madam, to peruse the poor endeavors of my Pen; for I have a Pen, tho' I say it, that—

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Pray let me see St. George for Christendom, or, The Seven Champions of England.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, no, give him, The Young Clerk's Guide. What, we shall have you read your self into a humor of Rambling, and Fighting, and studying Military Discipline, and wearing red Breeches!

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Nay, if you talk of Military Discipline, shew him my Treatise of The Art Military.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hold, I wou'd as willingly he shou'd read a Play.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: O pray, forsooth Mother, let me have a Play.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, there are young Students of the Law enough spoil'd already, by Playes; they wou'd make you in love with your Landress, or what's worse, some Queen of the Stage, that was a Landress; and so turn Keeper before you are of age. [Several crossing the Stage. But stay, Ierry, is not that Mr. what-d ' y' call-him, that goes there: he that offer'd to sell me a Suit in Chancery for five hundred pound, for a hundred down, and only paying the Clerks Fees?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Ay, forsooth, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then stay here, and have a care of the Bags, whil'st I follow him: have a care of the Bags, I say.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: And do you have a care, forsooth, of the Statute against Champer●ee, I say.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So, there's a limb of my Widow, which was wont to be inseparable from her: she can't be far. [Aside. How now, my pretty Son-in-law that shall be, where's my Widow?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: My Mother, but not your Widow, will be forthcoming presently.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Your Servant, Major; what, are you buying Furniture for a little sleeping Closet, which you miscall a Study? For you do only by your Books, as by your Wenches, bind 'em up neatly, and make 'em fine, for other people to use 'em: And your Bookseller is properly your Upholster; for he furnishes your Room, rather than your Head.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Well, well, good Sea-Lieutenant, study you your Compass, that's more than your head can deal with. (I will go find out the Widow, to keep her out of his sight, or he'll board her, whil'st I am treating a Peace.)

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Nay pr'ythee, Friend, now, let me have but the Seven Champipions, you shall trust me no longer than till my Mothers Mr. Splitcause comes; for I hope he'll lend me wherewithall to pay for't.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Lend thee! here, I'll pay him. Do you want Money, Squire? I'm sorry a Man of your Estate shou'd want Money.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Nay, my Mother will ne'r let me be at Age: And till then, she sayes—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: At Age! Why, you are at Age already, to have spent an Estate, Man; there are younger than you, have kept their Women these three Years, have had half a dozen Claps, and lost as many thousand pounds at Play.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Ay, they are happy Sparks! nay, I know some of my School-Fellows, who, when we were at School, were two Years younger than me; but now, I know not how, are grown Men before me, and go where they will, and look to themselves: but my Curmudgeonly Mother wo'nt allow me where withall to be a Man of my self with.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why there 'tis, I knew your Mother was in the fault: Ask but your School-Fellows what they did, to be Men of themselves.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Why, I know they went to Law with their Mothers; for they say, there's no good to be done upon a Widow Mother, till one goes to Law with her: but mine is as plaguy a Lawyer, as any's of our Inn. Then wou'd she marry too, and cut down my Trees: Now I shou'd hate, Man, to have my Father's● Wife kiss'd, and slap'd, and t'other thing too, (you know what I mean) by another Man; and our Trees are the purest, tall, even, shady twigs by my fa—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
Come, Squire, let your Mother and your Trees fall as she pleases ' rather than wear this Gown, and carry green Bags all thy life; and be pointed at for a Tony: But you shall be able to deal with her yet the common way; thou shalt make false Love to some Lawyer's daughter, whose Father, upon the hopes of thy marrying her, shall lend thee Money,
and Law, to preserve thy Estate and Trees; and thy Mother is so ugly, no Body will have her, if she cannot cut down thy Trees.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Nay, if I had but any Body to stand by me, I am as stomachful as another

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: That will I, I'll not see any hopeful young Gentleman abus'd.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: By any but your self.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: The truth on't is, mine's as arrant a Widow-Mother, to her poor Child, as any's in England: She wo'nt so much as let one have six-pence in one's Pocket, to see a Motion, or the Dancing of the Ropes, or—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Come, you sha'nt want Money, there's Gold for you.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: O Lurd, Sir, two Guineys! d'ye lend me this? is there no trick I'll? Well, Sir, I'll give you my Bond, for security.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No, no, thou hast given me thy face for security: Any Body wou'd swear, thou dost not look like a Cheat. You shall have what you will of me; and, if your Mother will not be kinder to you, come to me, who will.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: By my fa— he's a curious fine Gentleman!— [Aside. But, will you stand by one?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: If you can be resolute.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Can be resolv'd! Gad, if she gives me but a cross word, I'll leave her to night, and come to you. But, now I have got Money, I'll go to Iack of All Trades, at t'other end of the Hall, and buy the neatest, purest things—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And I'll follow the great Boy, and my blow at his Mother: steal way the Calf, and the Cow will follow you.

div.stage: Enter, on the other side, Manly, Widow Blackacre, and Oldfox.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Dam your Cause; can't you lose it without me? which you are like enough to do, if it be as you say, an honest one: I will suffer no longer for't.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, Captain, I tell you, you are my prime Witness, and the Cause is just now coming on, Mr. Splitcause tells me. Lord, methinks you shou'd take a pleasure in walking here, as half you see now do; for they have no business here, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Yes, but I'll assure you then, their business is to persecute me; but d'ye think I'll stay any longer, to have a Rogue, because he knows my name, pluck me aside, and whisper a Newsbook-secret to me, with a stinking breath? A second come piping angry from the Court, and sputter in my face his tedious complaints against it? A third Law-Coxcomb, because he saw me once at a Reader's dinner, come and put me a long Law-Case, to make a discovery of his indefatigable dulness, and my weari'd patience? A fourth, a most barbarous civil Rogue, who will keep a Man half
an hour in the croud with a bow'd body, and a hat off, acting the reform'd Sign of the Salutation Tavern, to hear his bountiful professions of service and friendship; whil'st he cares not if I were damn'd, and I am wishing him hang'd out of my way? I'd as soon run the Gantlet, as walk t'other turn.

div.stage: Enter to them Jerry Blackacre without his Bags; but laden with Trinkets, which he endeavors to hide from his Mother: and follow'd at a distance by Freeman.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O, are you come, Sir? But where have you been, you Ass? And how come you thus laden?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Look here, forsooth Mother, now here's a Duck, here's a Boarcat, and here's an Owl.

div.stage: [Making a noise with Cat-calls, and other such like Instruments.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes, there is an Owl, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: He's an ungracious Bird, indeed.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But go, thou Trangame, and carry back those Trangames, which thou hast stol'n or purloin'd; for no Body wou'd trust a Minor in Westminster-hall sure.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Hold your self contented, forsooth, I have these Commodities by a fair Bargain and Sale; and there stands my Witness, and Creditor.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How's that! What, Sir, d'ye think to get the Mother, by giving the Child a Rattle? But where are my Bags, my Writings, you Rascal?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: O Law! Where are they indeed?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How, Sirrah? speak, come—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You can tell her, Freeman, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I made one of your Salt-water Sharks steal 'em, whil'st he was eagerly choosing his Commodities, as he calls 'em, in order to my design upon his Mother.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Wo'nt you speak? Where were you, I say, you Son of a— an unfortunate Woman? O, Major, I'm undone; they are all that concern my Estate, my Jointure, my Husband's Deed of Gift, my Evidences for all my Suits now depending! What will become of them?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear this. [Aside. They'll be safe, I warrant you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O where? where? Come, you Villain, along with me, and shew me where.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thou hast taken the right way to get a Widow, by making her great Boy Rebel; for, when nothing will make a Widow marry, she'll do't to cross her Children. But canst thou in earnest marry this Harpy, this Volume of shrivel'd blur'd Parchments and Law, this Attornies Desk?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I'll marry, and live honestly: that is, give my Creditors, not her, due Benevolence, pay my Debts.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thy Creditors, you see, are not so barbarous, as to put thee in Prison, and wilt thou commit thy self to a noisom Dungeon for thy life? which is the only satisfaction thou canst give thy Creditors, by this match.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why, is not she rich?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, but he that marries a Widow, for her Money, will find himself as much mistaken, as the Widow, that marries a young Fellow for due Benevolence, as you call it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why, d'ye think I sha'nt deserve Wages? I'll drudge faithfully.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I tell thee again, he that is the Slave in the Mine, has the least propriety in the Ore: You may dig, and dig; but, if thou wou'dst have her Money, rather get to be her Trustee, than her Husband, for a true Widow will make over her Estate to any Body, and cheat her self, rather than be cheated by her Children, or a second Husband.

div.stage: Enter to them Jerry, running in a fright.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: O Law! I'm undone, I'm undone, my Mother will kill me: You said you'd stand by one.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So I will, my brave Squire, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Ay, but I dare not stay till she comes; for she's as furious, now she has lost her Writings, as a Bitch when she has lost her Puppies.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The comparison's handsom!

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: O, she's here!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: [To the Sailor.] Take him, Iack, and make haste with him, to your Master's Lodging; and be sure you keep him up, till I come.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O my dear Writings! Where's this Heathen Rogue, my Minor?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Gone to drown, or hang himself.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, I know him too well, he'll ne'r be Felo de se that way, but he may go and choose a Guardian of his own head, and so be Felo de ses beins: for he has not yet chosen one.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Say you so? And he sha'nt want one.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But, now I think on't, 'tis you, Sir, have put this Cheat upon me; for there is a saying, Take hold of a Maid by her Smock, and a Widow by her Writings, and they cannot get from you: But I'll play fast and loose with you yet, if there be Law; and my Minor and Writings are not forth-coming, I'll bring my Action of Detinue or Trover. But first, I'll try to find out this Guardianless, graceless Villain. Will you jog, Major?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: If you have lost your Evidence, I hope your Causes cannot go on, and I may be gone?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O no, stay but a making Water while, (as one may say) and I'll be with you again.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well, sure I am the first Man that ever began a Love Intrigue, in Westminster-hall.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, sure; for the Love to a Widow generally begins here: And as the Widow's Cause goes against the Heir or Executors, the Jointure Rivals commence their Suit to the Widow.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well, but how, pray, have you past your time here, since I was forc'd to leave you alone? You have had a great deal of patience.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Is this a place to be alone, or have patience in? But I have had patience indeed; for I have drawn upon me, since I came, but three Quarrels, and two Law-Suits.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, faith, you are too curst to be let loose in the World; you shou'd be ty'd up again, in your Sea-kennel, call'd a Ship. But how cou'd you quarrel here?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How cou'd I refrain? A Lawyer talk'd peremptorily and saucily to me, and as good as gave me the Lye

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: They do it so often to one another at the Bar, that they make no Bones on't elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: However, I gave him a Cuff on the Ear; whereupon he jogs two Men, whose Backs were turn'd to us, (for they were reading at a Booksellers) to Witness I struck him sitting the Courts; which office they so readily promis'd that I call'd 'em Rascals and Knights of the Post: one of 'em presently calls two other absent Witnesses, who were coming towards us at a distance; whil'st the other, with a Whisper, desires to know my name, that he might have satisfaction by way of Challenge, as t'other by way of Writ; but if it were not rather to direct his Brother's Writ, than his own Challenge: there you see is one of my Quarrels, and two of my Law-Suits.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So:— and the other two?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: For advising a Poet to leave off Writing, and turn Lawyer, because he is dull, and impudent, and sayes or writes nothing now, but by Precedent.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And the third Quarrel?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: For giving more sincere Advice, to a handsom, well-drest, young Fellow (who ask'd it too) not to marry a Wench, that he lov'd, and I had lay'n with.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, if you will be giving your sincere advice to Lovers, and Poets, you will not fail of Quarrels.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Or, if I stay in this place; for I see more Quarrels crouding upon me: let's be gone, and avoid 'em. Enter Novel, at a distance, coming towards them. A Plague on him, that Sneer is ominous to us; he is coming upon us, and we shall not be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Dear Bully, don't look so grum upon me; you told me just now, you had forgiven me a little harmless Raillery upon wooden legs last night.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, yes, pray be gone, I am talking of business.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Can't I hear it? I love thee, and will be faithful, and alwayes—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Impertinent! 'Tis Business that concerns Freeman only.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Well, I love Freeman too, and wou'd not divulge his secret: pr'ythee speak, pr'ythee, I must—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Pr'ythee let me be rid of thee, I must be rid of thee.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Faith, thou canst hardly, I love thee so. Come, I must know the business.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So, I have it now. [Aside. Why, if you needs will know it, he has a quarrel, and his Adversary bids him bring two Friends with him: now, I am one; and we are thinking who we shall have for a third.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: A Pox, there goes a Fellow owes me an Hundred pound, and goes out of Town to morrow: I'll speak with him, and come to you preesently.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No but you wo' not.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You are dextrously rid of him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To what purpose, since here comes another, as impertinent? I know, by his grin, he is bound hither.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Your Servant, worthy, noble Captain: Well, I have left the Widow, because she carry'd me from your company; for, faith Captain, I must needs tell thee, thou art the only Officer in England, who was not an Edg-hill Officer, that I care for.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I'm sorry for't.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Why, wou'dst thou have me love them?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Any body, rather than me.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: What, you are modest I see! therefore too, I love thee.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, I am not modest, but love to brag my self, and can't patiently hear you fight over the last Civil War; therefore go look out the Fellow I saw just now here, that walks with his Stockings and his Sword out at heels, and let him tell you the History of that scar on his check, to give you occasion to shew yours, got in the field at Bloomsbury, not that of Edg-hill: go to him, poor Fellow, he is fasting, and has not yet the happiness this morning to stink of Brandy and Tobacco; go, give him some to hear you, I am busie.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Well, ygad, I love thee now, Boy, for thy surliness: thou art no tame Captain, I see, that will suffer—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: An old Fox.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: All that sha'nt make me angry: I consider thou art peevish, and fretting at some ill success at Law. Pr'ythee tell me what ill luck you have met with here.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Do I look like the Picture of ill Luck? Gadsnouns, I love thee more and more; and shall I tell thee what made me love thee first?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Do: that I may be rid of that damn'd quality, and thee.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: 'Twas thy wearing that broad Sword there.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Here, Freeman, let's change: I'll never wear it more.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: How! You wo' not sure. Pr'ythee don't look like one of our Holyday Captains now adayes, with a Bodkin by your side, your Martinet Rogues.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: (O, then there's hopes.) [Aside. What, d'ye find fault with Martinet? let me tell you, Sir, 'tis the best exercise in the World; the most ready, most easie, most graceful exercise that ever was us'd, and the most—

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Sir, no more, Sir, your Servant, if you praise Martinet once, I have done with you, Sir. Martinet! Martinet!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, you have made him leave you as willingly, as ever he did an Enemy; for he was truly for the King and Parliament: for the Parliament, in their List; and for the King, in cheating 'em of their Pay, and never hurting the King's party in the Field.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A Pox! this way; here's a Lawyer I know threatning us with another greeting.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, your very Servant; I was afraid you had forgotten me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I was not afraid you had forgotten me.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: No, Sir, we Lawyers have pretty good memories.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You ought to have, by your Wits.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: O, you are a merry Gentleman, Sir; I remember you were merry, when I was last in your company.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I was never merry in thy company, Mr. Lawyer, sure.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Why, I'm sure you jok'd upon me, and shamm'd me all night long.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Shamm'd! pr'ythee what barbarous Law-term is that?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Shamming! Why, don't you know that? 'tis all our way of Wit Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am glad I do not know it then: Shamming! What does he mean by't, Freeman?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Shamming, is telling you an insipid, dull Lyer with a dull Face, which the slie Wag the Author only laughs at himself; and making himself believe 'tis a good Jest, puts the Sham only upon himself.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So, your Lawyers Jest, I find, like his Practice, has more Knavery than Wit in't. I shou'd make the worst Shammer in England; I must alwayes deal ingeniously, as I will with you, Mr. Lawyer, and advise you to be seen rather with Attornies and Solicitors, than such Fellows as I am; they will credit your practice more.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: No, Sir, your company's an honour to me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, faith, go this way, there goes an Attorney, leave me for him: let it be never said, a Lawyers Civility did him hurt.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: No, worthy honour'd Sir, I'll not leave you for any Attorney sure.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Unless he had a Fee in his hand.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Have you any business here, Sir? try me: I'd serve you sooner than any Attorney breathing.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Business!— So, I have thought of a sure way. [Aside. Yes, faith, I have a little business.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Have you so, Sir? in what Court, Sir? what is't, Sir? tell me but how I may serve you, and I'll do't, Sir; and take it for as great an honour—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Faith, 'tis for a poor Orphan of a Sea-Officer of mine, that has no Money; but if it cou'd be follow'd in Forma Pauperis; and when the Legacy's recover'd—

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Forma Pauperis, Sir!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Mr. Bumblecase, Mr. Bumblecase, a word with you; Sir, I beg your pardon at present, I have a little business.—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Which is not in Forma Pauperis.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So, you have now found a way to be rid of people without quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But here's a City Rogue will stick as hard upon us, as if I ow'd him Money.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Captain, noble Sir, I am yours heartily d'ye see: Why shou'd you avoid your old Friends?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And why shou'd you follow me? I owe you nothing.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Out of my hearty respects to you; for there is not a Man in England.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thou wou'dst save from hanging, with the expence of a shilling only.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but Captain, you are like enough to tell me—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Truth, which you wo'nt care to hear; therefore you had better go talk with some body else.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: No, I know no body can inform me better, of some young Wit, or Spendthrift, that has a good dip'd Seat and Estate in Middlesex, Hartfordshire, Essex, or Kent, any of these wou'd serve my turn: now, if you knew of such an one, and wou'd but help—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You to finish his ruine.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I faith, you shou'd have a snip—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Of your Nose; you thirty in the hundred Rascal, wou'd you make me your Squire Setter, your Baud for Mannors?

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Hold, or here will be your third Law-Suit.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Gads precious, you hectoring person you, are you wild? I meant you no hurt, Sir; I begin to think (as things go) Land security best, and have, for a convenient Mortgage, some ten, fifteen, or twenty thousand pound by me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Then go lay it out upon an Hospital, and take a Mortgage of Heaven, according to your City custom; for you think, by laying out a little Money, to hook in that too hereafter: do, I say, and keep the Poor you've made, by taking forfeitures, that Heaven may not take yours

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: No, to keep the Cripples you make this War; this War spoils our Trade.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Dam your Trade, 'tis the better for't.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: What, will you speak against our Trade?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And dare you speak against the War, our Trade?

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
Well, he may be a Convoy of ships I am concern'd in. [Aside.
Come, Captain, I will have a fair correspondency with you, say what you will.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Then pr'ythee be gone.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: No, faith; pr'ythee, Captain, let's go drink a Dish of Lac'd Coffee, and talk of the Times: Come, I'll treat you; nay, you shall go, for I have no business here.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But I have.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: To pick up a Man to give thee a Dinner? Come, I'll do thy business for thee.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Faith, now I think on't, so you may, as well as any Man; for 'tis to pick up a Man, to be bound with me, to one who expects City security, for—

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Nay, then your Servant, Captain; business must be done.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, if it can; but hark you, Alderman, without you—

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Business Sir, I say, must be done; and there's an Officer of the Treasury I have an Affair with—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You see now what the mighty friendship of the World is; what all Ceremony, Embraces, and plentiful Professions come to: You are no more to believe a professing Friend, than a threatning Enemy; and as no Man hurts you, that tells you he'll do you a mischief, no man, you see, is your Servant, who sayes he is so. Why, the Devil, then shou'd a Man be troubled with the flattery of Knaves, if he be not a Fool, or Cully; or with the fondness of Fools, if he be not a Knave, or Cheat?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Only for his pleasure; for there is some in laughing at Fools, and disappointing Knaves.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That's a pleasure, I think, wou'd cost you too dear, as well as marrying your Widow to disappoint her; but, for my part, I have no pleasure by 'em, but in despising 'em, wheresoe'r I meet 'em; and then, the pleasure of hoping so to be rid of 'em. But now my comfort is, I am not worth a shilling in the World, which all the World shall know; and then I'm sure I shall have none of 'em come near me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: A very pretty comfort, which I think you pay too dear for: But is the twenty pound gone since the morning?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To my Boats Crew: Wou'd you have the poor, honest, brave Fellows want?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Rather than you, or I.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why, art thou without Money? thou who art a Friend to every Body?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I ventur'd my last stake upon the Squire, to nick him of his Mother; and cannot help you to a dinner, unless you will go dine with my Lord—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, no, the Ordinary is too dear for me, where flattery must pay for my dinner: I am no Herald, or Poet.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: We'll go then to the Bishops—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: There you must flatter the old Philosophy: I cannot renounce my reason for a dinner.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why, then let's go to your Aldermans.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Hang him, Rogue! that were not to dine; for he makes you drunk with Lees of Sack before dinner, to take away your stomach: and there you must call Usury and Extortion, Gods blessings, or the honest turning of the Penny; hear him brag of the leather Breeches in which he trotted first to Town; and make a greater noise with his Money in his Parlor, than his Casheers do in his Counting house, without hopes of borrowing a shilling.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, a pox on't, 'tis like dining with the great Gamesters; and, when they fall to their common Dessert, see the heaps of Gold drawn on all hands, without going to twelve. Let us go to my Lady Goodly's.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: There, to slatter her looks, you must mistake her Grandchildren for her own; praise her Cook, that she may rail at him: and feed her Dogs, not your self.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What d'ye think of eating with your Lawyer then?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Eat with him! Dam him; to hear him employ his barbarous eloquence in a Reading upon the two and thirty good Bits in a shoulder of Veal; and be forc'd your self to praise the cold Bribe pye, that stinks; and drink Law-French Wine, as rough and harsh, as his Law-French. A pox on him, I'd rather dine in the Temple Rounds, or Walks, with the Knights without Noses, or the Knights of the Post; who are honester Fellows, and better company. But let us home, and try our Fortune; for I'll stay no longer here, for your damn'd Widow.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well, let us go home then; for I must go for my damn'd Widow, and look after my new damn'd Charge; three or four hundred Year ago, a Man might have din'd in this Hall.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But now, the Lawyer only here is fed:
And, Bully-like, by Quarrels gets his Bread.

div.head: ACT. IV. Scene 1.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: WEll, there's success in thy face; hast thou prevail'd? say.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: As I cou'd wish, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So, I told thee what thou wert fit for, and thou wou'dst not believe me. Come, thank me for bringing thee acquainted with thy Genius. Well, thou hast mollifi'd her heart for me?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: No, Sir, not so; but what's better.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How? what's better!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I shall harden your heart against her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Have a care, Sir, my heart is too much in earnest to be fool'd with, and my desire at heighth, and needs no delayes to incite it; what, you are too good a Pimp already, and know how to endear pleasure, by with-holding it? but leave off your Pages, Baudy-house tricks, Sir, and tell me, will she be kind?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Kinder than you cou'd wish, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So then: well, pr'ythee what said she?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: She said—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What? thou'rt so tedious; speak comfort to me: what?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: That, of all things, you were her aversion.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: That she wou'd sooner take a Bedfellow out of an Hospital, and Diseases, into her Arms, than you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: That she wou'd rather trust her Honour with a dissolute, debauch'd Hector; nay worse, with a finical baffled Coward, all over loathsom with affectation of the fine Gentleman;

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What's all this you say?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nay, that my offers of your Love to her, were more offensive, than when Parents wooe their Virgin Daughters, to the enjoyment of Riches onely; and that you were, in all circumstances, as nauseous to her, as a Husband on compulsion.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Hold; I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: So, 'twill work I see.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Did not you tell me—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: She call'd you ten thousand Ruffins.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Hold, I say.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Brutes—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Sea-Monsters—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Dam your intelligence: hear me a little now.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nay, surly Coward she call'd you too.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Won't you hold yet? hold, or—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, pardon me; I cou'd not but tell you she had the baseness, the injustice, to call you Coward, Sir, Coward, Coward, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Not yet?—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I've done. Coward, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Did not you say she was kinder than I cou'd wish her?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How then?— O— I understand you now. At first, she appear'd in rage, and disdain, the truest sign of a coming Woman; but, at last, you prevail'd it seems: did you not?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So then, let's know that only; come, pr'ythee, without delays: I'll kiss thee for that News before hand.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: So; the Kiss, I'm sure, is welcom to me, whatsoe're the News will be to you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Come, speak, my dear Voluntier.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: How welcome were that kind word too, if it were not for another Womans sake!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What, won't you speak? You prevail'd for me, at last, you say?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No more of your fooling, Sir; it will not agree with my impatience, or temper.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Then, not to fool you, Sir, I spoke to her for you, but prevail'd for my self; she wou'd not hear me when I spoke in your behalf; but bid me say what I wou'd in my own, tho' she gave me no occasion, she was so coming: and so was kinder, Sir, than you cou'd wish; which I was only afraid to let you know, without some warning.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How's this? Young man, you are of a lying age; but I must hear you out, and if—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I wou'd not abuse you, and cannot wrong her by any report of her, she is so wicked.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How, wicked! had she the impudence, at the second sight of you only—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Impudence, Sir! Oh, she has impudence enough to put a Court out of countenance, and debauch a Stews.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why, what said she?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Her tongue, I confess, was silent; but her speaking Eyes gloted such things, more immodest, and lascivious, than Ravishers can act, or Women under a confinement think.

sp.speaker: Man.
