sp.p: I know there are whose Eyes reflect more Obscenity, than the Glasses in Alcoves; but there are others too who use a little Art with their looks, to make 'em seem more beautiful, not more loving: which vain young Fellows, like you, are apt to interpret in their own favor, and to the Lady's wrong.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Seldom, Sir; pray have you a care of gloting Eyes; for he that loves to gaze upon 'em, will find, at last, a thousand Fools and Cuckolds in 'em, instead of Cupids.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Very well, Sir: but, what, you had only eye-kindness from Olivia?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I tell you again, Sir, no Woman sticks there: Eye-promises of Love they only keep; nay, they are Contracts which make you sure of 'em. In short, Sir, she, seeing me, with shame and amazement dumb, unactive, and resistless, threw her twisting arms about my neck, and smother'd me with a thousand tasteless Kisses: believe me, Sir, they were so to me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why did you not avoid 'em then?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I fenced with her eager Arms, as you did with the grapples of the Enemy's Fireship; and nothing but cutting 'em off, cou'd have freed me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Damn'd, damn'd Woman, that cou'd be so false and infamous! And damn'd, damn'd heart of mine, that cannot yet be false, tho' so infamous! What easie, tame, suffering, trampled things does that little God of talking Cowards make of us! but—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: So! it works I find as I expected.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But she was false to me before, she told me so her self, and yet I cou'd not quite believe it; but she was, so that her second falseness is a favor to me, not an injury, in revenging me upon the Man that wrong'd me first of her Love. Her Love!— a Whores, a Witches Love!— But, what, did she not kiss well, Sir? I'm sure I thought her Lips— but I must not think of 'em more— but yet they are such I cou'd still kiss,— grow to and then tear off with my teeth, grind 'em into mammocks, and spit 'em into her Cuckolds face.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Poor man, how uneasie he is! I have hardly the heart to give him so much pain, tho' withall I give him a cure; and to my self new life.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But, what, her Kisses sure cou'd not but warm you into desire at last, or a compliance with hers at least?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nay more, I confess—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What more? speak.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: All you cou'd fear had pass'd between us, if I cou'd have been made to wrong you; Sir, in that nature.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Cou'd have been made! you lie, you did.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, 'twas impossible for me; besides, we were interrupted by a visit; but, I confess, she would not let me stir, till I promis'd to return to her again, within this hour, as soon as it shou'd be dark; by which time, she wou'd dispose of her visit, and her servants, and her self, for my reception: which I was fain to promise to get from her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: But if ever I go near her again, may you, Sir, think me as false to you, as she is; hate, and renounce me; as you ought to do her, and I hope will do now.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Well, but now I think on't, you shall keep your word with your Lady. What, a young Fellow, and fail the first, nay, so tempting an assignation!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I say you shall go to her when 'tis dark, and shall not disappoint her.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I, Sir! I shou'd disappoint her more by going; for—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Her impudence, and injustice to you, will make me disappoint her Love; loath her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Come, you have my leave; and if you disgust her, I'll go with you, and act Love, whil'st you shall talk it only.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: You, Sir! nay, then I'll never go near her. You act Love, Sir! You must but act it indeed, after all I have said to you. Think of your Honour, Sir, Love—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Well, call it Revenge, and that is Honourable: I'll be reveng'd on her; and thou shalt be my second.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Not in a base action, Sir, when you are your own Enemy: O go not near her, Sir, for Heav'ns sake, for your own, think not of it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How concern'd you are! I thought I shou'd catch you. What, you are my Rival at last, and are in Love with her your self; and have spoken ill of her, out of your Love to her, not me; and therefore wou'd not have me go to her!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Heav'n witness for me, 'tis because I love you only, I wou'd not have you go to her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Come, come, the more I think on't, the more I'm satisfi'd you do love her: those Kisses, young Man, I knew were irresistible; tis certain.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: There is nothing certain in the World, Sir, but my Truth, and your Courage.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir. Besides false, and ungrateful, as she has been to me; and tho' I may believe her hatred to me, great as you report it; yet I cannot think you are so soon, and at that rate, belov'd by her, tho' you may endeavor it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nay, if that be all, and you doubt it still, Sir, I will conduct you to her; and, unseen, your Ears shall judge of her falseness, and my Truth to you: if that will satisfie you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, there is some satisfaction in being quite out of doubt: because 'tis that alone with-holds us from the pleasure of Revenge.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Revenge! What Revenge can you have, Sir? Disdain is best reveng'd by scorn; and faithless Love, by loving another, and making her happy with the others losings: which, if I might advise—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Not a word more.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: What are you talking of Love yet, Captain? I thought you had done with't.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why, what did you hear me say?

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Something imperfectly of Love, I think.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I was only wond'ring why Fools, Rascals, and desertless Wretches, shou'd still have the better of Men of Merit, with all Women; as much as with their own common Mistress, Fortune!

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Because most Women, like Fortune, are blind, seem to do all things in jest, and take pleasure in extravagant actions; their love deserves neither thanks, or blame, for they cannot help it: 'tis all sympathy; therefore the noise, the finical, the talkative, the cowardly and effeminate, have the better of the brave, the reasonable, and Man of Honour; for they have no more reason in their love, or kindness, than Fortune her self.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, they have their reason. First, Honour in a Man they fear too much to love; and Sence in a Lover, upbraids their want of it; and they hate any thing that disturbs their admiration of themselves; but they are of that vain number, who had rather shew their false generosity, in giving away profusely to worthless Flatterers, than in paying just Debts: And, in short, all Women, like Fortune, (as you say) and Rewards, are lost, by too much meriting.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: All Women, Sir! sure there are some, who have no other quarrel to a Lovers merit, but that it begets their despair of him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thou art young enough to be credulous; but we—

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p: Here are now below, the scolding, daggled Gentlewoman, and that Major Old— old— Fop, I think you call him.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Oldfox: pr'ythee bid 'em come up, with your leave, Captain, for now I can talk with her upon the square; if I shall not disturb you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No; for I'd be gone. Come, Voluntier,

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Nay, pray stay; the Scene between us will not be so tedious to you, as you think: besides, you shall see, how I have rigg'd my Squire out, with the remains of my shipwrack'd Wardrobe; he is under your Sea-Valet de Chambre's hands, and by this time drest, and will be worth your seeing. Stay, and I'll fetch my Fool.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No; you know I cannot easily laugh: besides, my Voluntier and I have business abroad.

div.stage: [Ex. Manly, Fidelia on one side, Freeman on t'other.
Enter Major Oldfox, and Widow Blackacre.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What, no body here! Did not the Fellow say he was within?

sp.speaker: Oldf.
sp.p: Yes, Lady; and he may be perhaps a little busie at present; but, if you think the time long till he comes, [Vnfolding Papers] I'll read you here some of the fruit of my leisure, the overflowings of my fancy and Pen. (To value me right, she must know my parts.) [Aside. Come—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, no; I have reading work enough of my own, in my Bag, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Oldf.
sp.p: I, Law, Madam; but here is a Poem, in blank Verse, which I think a handsom Declaration of one's Passion.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O! if you talk of Declarations, I'll shew you one of the prettiest pen'd things, which I mended too my self you must know;

sp.speaker: Oldf.
sp.p: Nay, Lady, if you have us'd your self so much to the reading of harsh Law, that you hate smooth Poetry; here is a Character for you, of—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A Character! Nay, then I'll shew you my Bill in Chancery here, that gives you such a Character of my Adversary, makes him as black—

sp.speaker: Oldf.
sp.p: Pshaw; away, away, Lady. But if you think the Character too long, here is an Epigram not above 20 Lines, upon a cruel Lady; who Decreed her Servant shou'd hang himself, to demonstrate his Passion.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Decreed! if you talk of Decreeing, I have such a Decree here, drawn by the finest Clerk—

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
O Lady, Lady, all interruption, and no sence between us, as if we were Lawyers at the Bar! But I had forgot, Apollo and Littleton never lodge in a head together. If you hate Verses, I'll give you a cast of my Politics in Prose: 'tis a Letter to a Friend in the Countrey; which is now the way of all such sober, solid persons as my self, when they have a mind to publish their disgust to the Times; tho' perhaps, between you and I, they have no Friend in the Countrey. And sure a Politic, serious person may as well have a feign'd Friend in the Countrey to write to, as well as an idle Poet a feign'd Mistress to write to. And so here is my Letter
to a Friend, or no Friend, in the Countrey, concerning the late conjuncture of Affairs, in relation to Coffee-houses: or the Coffee-man's Case.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, if your Letter have a Case in't, 'tis something; but first I'll read you a Letter of mine, to a Friend in the Countrey, call'd a Letter of Attorney.

div.stage: Enter to them Freeman, and Jerry Blackacre, in an old gaudy Suit, and Red Breeches of Freeman's.

sp.speaker: Oldf.
sp.p: What, Interruption still? O the plague of Interruption! worse to an Author, than the plague of Critics!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What's this I see, Ierry Blackacre, my Minor, in Red Breeches! What, hast thou left the modest seemly Garb of Gown and Cap, for this? And have I lost all my good Inns of Chancery breeding upon thee then? And thou wilt go a breeding thy self, from our Inn of Chancery and Westminster-hall, at Coffee-houses and Ordinaries, Play-houses, Tennis-courts, and Baudy-houses.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Ay, ay, what then? perhaps I will; but what's that to you? here's my Guardian and Tutor now forsooth, that I am out of your Hucksters hands.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How? thou hast not chosen him for thy Guardian yet?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: No, but he has chosen me for his Charge, and that's all one; and I'll do any thing he'll have me, and go all the World over with him; to Ordinaries, and Baudy-houses, or any where else.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: To Ordinaries and Baudy-houses I have a care, Minor, thou wilt infeeble there thy Estate, and Body: do not go to Ordinaries and Baudy-houses, good Ierry.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Why, how come you to know any ill by Baudy-houses? You never had any hurt by 'em, had you, forsooth? Pray hold your self contented; if I do go where Money and Wenches are to be had, you may thank your self; for you us'd me so unnaturally, you wou'd never let me have a Penny to go abroad with; nor so much as come near the Garret, where your Maidens lay; nay, you wou'd not so much as let me play at Hotcockles with 'em, nor have any Recreation with 'em, tho' one shou'd have kist you behind, you were so unnatural a Mother, so you were.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Ay, a very unnatural Mother, faith, Squire.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But, Ierry, consider thou art yet but a Minor; however, if thou wilt go home with me again, and be a good Child, thou shalt see—

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Madam, I must have a better care of my Heir under age, than so; I wou'd sooner trust him alone with a stale Waiting-woman and a Parson, than with his Widow Mother and her Lover or Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, thou Villain, part Mother and Minor! Rob me of my Child and my Writings! but thou shalt find there's Law; and as in the Case of Ravishment, of Guard— Westminster the Second.

sp.speaker: Oldf.
sp.p: Young Gentleman, Squire, pray be rul'd by your Mother, and your Friends.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Yes, I'll be rul'd by my Friends, therefore not by my Mother, so I won't: I'll choose him for my Guardian till I am of age; nay, may be for as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Wilt thou so, thou Wretch? And when thou'rt of age, thou wilt Sign, Seal, and Deliver too, wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Yes marry will I, if you go there too.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O do not squeeze Wax, Son; rather go to Ordinaries, and Baudy-houses, than squeeze Wax: if thou dost that, farewell the goodly Mannor of Blackacre, with all its Woods, Underwoods, and Appurtenances whatever. Oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Come, Madam, in short, you see I am resolv'd to have a share in the Estate, yours or your Sons; if I cannot get you, I'll keep him, who is less coy you find; but, if you wou'd have your Son again, you must take me too. Peace, or War? Love, or Law? You see my Hostage is in my hand: I'm in possession.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, if one of us must be ruin'd, e'en let it be him. By my Body, a good one! Did you ever know yet a Widow marry or not marry for the sake of her Child? I'd have you to know, Sir, I shall be hard enough for you both yet, without marrying you: if Ierry won't be rul'd by me, what say you, Booby, will you be rul'd? speak.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Let one alone, can't you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Wilt thou choose him for Guardian, whom I refuse for Husband?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Ay, to choose, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And are all my hopes frustrated? Shall I never hear thee put Cases again to Iohn the Butler, or our Vicar? Never see thee amble the Circuit with the Judges; and hear thee, in our Town-Hall, louder than the Cryer?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: No; for I have taken my leave of Lawyering, and Pettifogging.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pettifogging! thou prophane Villain, hast thou so? Pettifogging!— then you shall take your leave of me, and your Estate too; thou shalt be an Alien to me and it for ever. Pettifogging!

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: O, but if you go there too, Mother, we have the Deeds, and Settlements, I thank you: Wou'd you cheat me of my Estate, isac?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, no, I will not cheat your little Brother Bob; for thou wert not born in Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: How? What Quirk has she got in her head now?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I say thou canst not, shalt not inherit the Blackacres Estate.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Why? Why, forsooth? What d'ye mean, if you go there to?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Thou art but my base Child; and, according to the Law, canst not inherit it: nay, thou art not so much as Bastard eigne.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: What, what? Am I then the Son of a Whore, Mother?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: The Law says—

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Madam, we know what the Law says; but have a care what you say: do not let your Passion, to ruine your Son, ruine your Reputation.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hang Reputation, Sir, am not I a Widow? Have no Husband, nor intend to have any? Nor wou'd you, I suppose, now have me for a Wife. So, I think now I'm reveng'd on my Son and you, without marrying, as I told you.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: But, consider, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: What, have you no shame left in you Mother?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Wonder not at it, Major, 'tis often the poor prest Widows case, to give up her Honour to save her Jointure; and seem to be a light Woman, rather than marry: as some young men, they say, pretend to have the filthy Disease, and lose their credit with most Women, to avoid the importunities of some.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: But one word with you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, no, Sir. Come, Major, let us make haste, now to the Prerogative Court.

sp.speaker: Oldf.
sp.p: But, Lady, if what you say be true, will you stigmatize your Reputation on Record? And, if it be not true, how will you prove it?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pshaw! I can prove any thing; and for my Reputation, know, Major, a wise Woman will no more value her Reputation in disinheriting a Rebellious Son, of a good Estate; than she wou'd in getting him, to inherit an Estate.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Madam— We must not let her go so, Squire.

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Nay, the Devil can't stop her tho' if she has a mind to't. But come, Bully Guardian, we'll go and advise with three Attornies, two Proctors, two Solicitors, and a shrewd man of White Friers, neither Attorney, Proctor, or Solicitor, but as pure a Pimp to the Law as any of 'em; and sure all they will be hard enough for her: for I fear, Bully Guardian, you are too good a Joker, to have any Law in your head.

sp.speaker: Freem.
sp.p: Thou'rt in the right on't, Squire; I understand no Law: especially that against Bastards, since I'm sure the Custom is against that Law; and more people get Estates by being so, than lose 'em.

div.stage: The Scene changes to Olivia's Lodging.
Enter Lord Plausible, and Boy with a Candle.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Little Gentleman, your most obedient, faithful, humble Servant: where, I beseech you, is that Divine person your Noble Lady?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Gone out, my Lord; but commanded me to give you this Letter.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Which he must not observe [Aside.] Puts it up.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Hey, Boy, where is thy Lady?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Gone out, Sir; but I must beg a word with you.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: For me? So. [Puts up the Letter. Servant, Servant, my Lord; you see the Lady knew of your coming, for she is gone out.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Sir, I humbly beseech you not to censure the Lady's good breeding: she has reason to use more liberty with me, than with any other man.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: How, Vicount, how?

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Nay, I humbly beseech you, be not in choler; where there is most love, there may be most freedom.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis time to come to an eclercisment with you, and to tell you, you must think no more of this Lady's love.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Why, under correction, dear Sir?

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: There are Reasons, Reasons, Vicount.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: What, I beseech you, Noble Sir?

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Pr'ythee, pr'ythee be not impertinent, my Lord; some of you Lords are such conceited, well-assur'd, impertinent Rogues;

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: And you noble Wits, are so full of shamming, and droling, one knows not where to have you, seriously.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Well, you shall find me in Bed, with this Lady, one of these dayes.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech you, spare the Lady's Honour; for her's and mine will be all one shortly.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p:
Pr'ythee, my Lord, be not an Ass: dost thou think to get her
from me? I have had such encouragements—

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: I have not been thought unworthy of 'em.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: What not like mine! Come to an eclercisment, as I said.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Why, seriously then, she has told me, Vicountess founded prettily.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: And me, that Novel was a name she wou'd sooner change her's for, than for any Title in England.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: She has commended the softness, and respectfulness of my behaviour.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: She has prais'd the briskness of my Railery of all things, Man.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: The sleepiness of my Eyes she lik'd.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Sleepiness! dulness, dulness. But the fierceness of mine she ador'd.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: The brightness of my hair she lik'd.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: The brightness! No, the greasiness, I warrant. But the blackness, and lustre of mine, she admires.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: The gentleness of my smile.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: The subtilty of my leer.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: The clearness of my complexion.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: The redness of my lips.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: The whiteness of my teeth.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: My janty way of picking them.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: The sweetness of my breath.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Hah ha!— Nay then she abus'd you, 'tis plain; for you know what Manly said: the sweetness of your Pulvillio she might mean; but for your breath! ha, ha, ha. Your breath is such, Man, that nothing but Tobacco can perfume: and your Complexion nothing cou'd mend, but the Small Pox.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you may please to be merry; but, to put you out of all doubt, Sir, she has receiv'd some Jewels from me, of value.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: And Presents from me; besides what I presented her jantily, by way of ' Ombre, of three or four hundred pound value, which I'm, sure are the earnest Pence for our Love bargain.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Nay then, Sir, with your favor, and to make an end of all your hopes, look you there, Sir, she has writ to me.—

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: How! how! Well, well, and so she has to me look you there.—

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: What's here!

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: How's this?

body.p: YOu'll excuse me, for breaking my word with you, since 'twas to oblige, not offend you; for I am only gone abroad but to disappoint Novel, and meet you in the Drawing-room; where I expect you, with as much impatience, as when I us'd to suffer Novel's Visits, the most impertinent Fop, that ever affected the name of a Wit, therefore not capable, I hope, to give you jealousie; for, for your sake alone, you saw, I renounc'd an old Lover, and will do all the World. Burn the Letter, but lay up the kindness of it in your heart, with your

sp.p: Very fine! but pray let's see mine.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: I understand it not; but sure she cannot think so of me.

sp.speaker: Nov.

body.p: HVmh! ha!— meet— for your sake— umh— quitted an old Lover— World— Burn— in your heart, with your

sp.p: Just the same, the names only alter'd

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: Surely there must be some mistake; or some body has abus'd her, and us.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Yes, you are abus'd, no doubt on't, my Lord; but I'll to White-hall, and see.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: And I, where I shall find you are abus'd.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Where, if it be so, for our comfort, we cannot fail of meeting with Fellow-sufferers enough; for, as Freeman said of another, she stands in the Drawing-room, like the Glass, ready for all Comers to set their Gallantry by her: and, like the Glass too, lets no man go from her, unsatisfi'd with himself.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Both here, and just gone?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: But are you sure neither saw you deliver the other a Letter?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Madam, I am very sure.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Go then to the Old Exchange, to Westminster, Holbourn, and all the other places I told you of; I shall not need you these two hours: Be gone, and take the Candle with you, and be sure you leave word again below, I am gone out, to all that ask.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: And my new Lover will not ask I'm sure; he has his Lesson, and cannot miss me here, tho' in the dark: which I have purposely design'd, as a remedy against my blushing Gallant's modesty; for young Lovers, like game Cocks, are made bolder, by being kept without light.

div.stage: Enter her husband Vernish, as from a Iourney.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Where is she? Darkness everywhere!

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What, come before your time? my Soul! my Life! your haste has augmented your kindness; and let me thank you for it thus, and thus— [Embracing and kissing him.] And tho' (my Soul) the little time since you left me, has seem'd an Age to my impatience, sure it is yet but seven—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: How! who's that you expected after seven?

sp.speaker: Oliv
sp.p: Ha! my Husband return'd! and have I been throwing away so many kind Kisses on my Husband, and wrong'd my Lover already?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Speak, I say, who was't you expected after seven?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What shall I say?— oh— [Aside. Why, 'tis but seven days, is it, dearest, since you went out of Town? and I expected you not so soon.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: No, sure, 'tis but five days since I left you.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Pardon my impatience, dearest, I thought 'em seven at least.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Nay then—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: But, my life, you shall never stay half so long from me again; you shan't, indeed, by this kiss, you shan't.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: No, no; but why alone in the dark?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Blame not my melancholy in your absence— But, my Soul, since you went, I have strange News to tell you: Manly is return'd.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Manly return'd! Fortune forbid.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Met with the Dutch in the Channel, fought, sunk his ship, and all he carri'd with him: he was here with me yesterday.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: And did you own our Marriage to him?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I told him I was marry'd, to put an end to his love, and my trouble; but to whom, is yet a secret kept from him, and all the World: And I have us'd him so scurvily, his great spirit will ne'r return, to reason it farther with me; I have sent him to Sea again, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: 'Twas bravely done. And sure he will now hate the shore more than ever, after so great a disappointment. Be you sure only to keep awhile our great secret, till he be gone: in the mean time, I'll lead the easie honest Fool by the Nose, as I us'd to do; and, whil'st he stays, rail with him at thee; and, when he's gone, laugh with thee at him. But have you his Cabinet of Jewels safe? Part not with a Seed Pearl to him, to keep him from starving.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Nor from hanging.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: He cannot recover 'em, and, I think, will scorn to beg 'em again.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: But, my life, have you taken the thousand Guineys he left in my name, out of the Goldsmiths hands?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ay, ay, they are remov'd to another Goldsmiths.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Ay but, my Soul, you had best have a care he find not where the money is; for his present wants (as I'm inform'd) are such, as will make him inquisitive enough.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: You say true, and he knows the man too: but I'll remove it to morrow.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: To morrow! O do not stay till to morrow: go to night, immediately.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Now I think on't, you advise well, and I will go presently.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Presently! instantly: I will not let you stay a jot.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I will then, tho' I return not home till twelve.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p:
Nay, tho' not till morning, with all my heart: go, dearest, I am impatient till you are gone— [Thrusts him out. So, I have at once now brought about those two grateful businesses, which all prudent Women do together, secur'd money and pleasure; and now all interruptions of the last are remov'd. Go Husband, and come up Friend; just the Bucket's in the Well: the absence of one brings the other; but I hope, like them too, they will not meet in the way, justle, and clash together.
Enter Fidelia, and Manly treading softly, and staying behind at some distance. So, are you come? (but not the Husband-bucket, I hope, again.) Who's there? my dearest?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: My life—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Right, right: where are thy lips? here, take the dumb, and best Welcomes, Kisses and Embraces; 'tis not a time for idle words. In a a Duel of Love, as in others, Parlying shews basely. Come, we are alone; and now the Word is only Satisfaction, and defend not thy self.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How's this? Wuh, she makes Love like a Devil in a Play; and in this darkness, which conceals her Angels face; if I were apt to be afraid, I shou'd think her a Devil.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What, you traverse ground, young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I take breath only.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Good Heav'ns! how was I deceiv'd!

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Nay, you are a Coward; what are you afraid of the fierceness of my Love?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, lest its violence might presage its change; and I must needs be afraid you wou'd leave me quickly, who cou'd desert so brave a Gentleman as Manly.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: O! name not his Name; for in a time of stol'n joys, as this is, the filthy name of Husband were not a more alaying sound.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: There's some comfort yet.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: But did you not love him?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Never. How cou'd you think it?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Because he thought it, who is a Man of that sence, nice discerning, and diffidency, that I shou'd think it hard to deceive him.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: No; he that distrusts most the World, trusts most to himself, and is but the more easily deceiv'd, because he thinks he can't be deceiv'd: his cunning is like the Coward's Sword, by which he is oftner worsted, than defended.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Yet, sure, you us'd no common Art, to deceive him.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I knew he lov'd his own singular moroseness so well, as to dote upon any Copy of it; wherefore I feign'd an hatred to the World too, that he might love me in earnest: but, if it had been hard to deceive him, I'm sure 'twere much harder to love him. A dogged, ill-manner'd—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: D'ye hear her, Sir? pray hear her.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Surly, untractable, snarling Brute! he! a Masty Dog were as fit a thing to make a Gallant of.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, a Goat, or Monky were fitter for thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I must confess, for my part, (tho' my Rival) I cannot but say, he has a Manly handsomness in's face and meen.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: So has a Saracen in the sign.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Is proper, and well made,

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: As a Drayman.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Has Wit,

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: He rails at all Mankind.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And undoubted Corage,

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Like the Hangman's, can murder a Man when his hands are ty'd. He has Cruelty indeed; which is no more Corage, than his Railing is Wit..

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thus Women, and Men like Women, are too hard for us, when they think we do not hear 'em; and Reputation, like other Mistresses, is never true to a Man in his absence.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: He is—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Pr'ythee no more of him; I thought I had satisfi'd you enough before, that he cou'd never be a Rival for you to apprehend; and you need not be more assur'd of my aversion to him, but by the last testimony of my love to you: which I am ready to give you. Come, my Soul, this way—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: But, Madam, what cou'd make you dissemble Love to him, when 'twas so hard a thing for you, and flatter his Love to you?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: That which makes all the World flatter and dissemble, 'twas his Money: I had a real passion for that. Yet I lov'd not that so well, as for it to take him; for, as soon as I had his Money, I hastened his departure: like a Wife, who, when she has made the most of a dying Husband's breath, pulls away the Pillow.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Damn'd Money! it's Master's potent Rival still; and, like a fancy Pimp, corrupts, it self, the Mistress it procures for us.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: But I did not think with you, my life, to pass my time in talking. Come hither, come; yet stay, till I have lock'd a door in the other Room, that might chance to let us in some interruption; which reciting Poets, or losing Gamesters, fear not more than I at this time do.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Well, I hope you are now satisfi'd, Sir, and will be gone, to think of your Revenge.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, I am not satisfi'd, and must stay to be Reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: How, Sir? You'll use no violence to her, I hope, and forfeit your own life, to take away hers? That were no Revenge.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, no, you need not fear: my Revenge shall only be upon her honour, not her life.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: How, Sir? her honour? O Heav'ns! Consider, Sir, she has no honour. D'ye call that Revenge? Can you think of such a thing? But reflect, Sir, how she hates and loaths you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, so much she hates me, that it wou'd be a Revenge sufficient, to make her accessary to my pleasure, and then let her know it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: No, Sir, no; to be Reveng'd on her now, were to disappoint her. Pray, Sir, let us be gone.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Hold off. What, you are my Rival then; and therefore you shall stay, and keep the door for me, whil'st I go in for you: but, when I'm gone, if you dare to stir off from this very Board, or breathe the least murmuring Accent, I'll cut her Throat first, and if you love her, you will not venture her life; nay, then I'll cut your Throat too; and I know you love your own life at least.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: But, Sir, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Not a word more, lest I begin my Revenge on her, by killing you.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: But are you sure 'tis Revenge, that makes you do this? how can it be?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Whist.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange Revenge indeed.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: If you make me stay, I shall keep my word, and begin with you: no more.

div.stage: [Exit Manly, at the same door Olivia went.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: O Heav'ns! is there not punishment enough
In loving well, if you will have't a Crime;
But you must add fresh Torments daily to't,
And punish us like peevish Rivals still,
Because we fain wou'd find a Heaven here?
But did there never any love like me,
That, untry'd Tortures, you must find me out?
Others, at worst, you force to kill themselves;
But I must be Self-murd'ress of my love,
Yet will not grant me pow'r to end my life,
My cruel life; for when a Lover's hopes
Are dead, and gone, life is unmerciful.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I have thought better on't, I must not discover my self now, I am without Witnesses; for if I barely shou'd publish it, she wou'd deny it with as much impudence, as she wou'd act it again with this young Fellow here. Where are you?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Here— oh— now I suppose we may be gone.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I will, but not you; you must stay, and act the second part of a Lover: that is, talk kindness to her.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No disputing, Sir, you must: 'tis necessary to my design, of coming again to morrow night.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: What, can you come again then hither?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, and you must make the appointment, and an Apology for your leaving her so soon; for I have said not a word to her, but have kept your counsel, as I expect you shou'd do mine: do this faithfully, and I promise you here, you shall run my Fortune still, and we will never part as long as we live; but, if you do not do it, expect not to live.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: 'Tis hard, Sir; but such a consideration will make it easier: you won't forget your promise, Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, by Heav'ns. But I hear her coming.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Where is my life? run from me already! you do not love me, dearest; nay, you are angry with me; for you wou'd not so much as speak a kind word to me within: What was the reason?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I was transported too much.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: That's kind; but come, my Soul, what make you here? let us go in again; we may be surpriz'd in this Room, 'tis so near the stairs.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: No, we shall hear the better here, if any body shou'd come up.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Nay, I assure you, we shall be secure enough within: Come, come—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I am sick, and troubled with a sudden diziness; cannot stir yet.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Come, I have spirits within.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Oh!— don't you hear a noise, Madam?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: No, no, there is none: Come, come.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Indeed there is; and I love you so much, I must have a care of your Honour, if you wo' not, and go; but to come to you to morrow night, if you please.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: With all my Soul; but you must not go yet: Come, pr'ythee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Oh!— I am now sicker, and am afraid of one of my Fits.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What Fits?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Of the Falling-sickness: and I lie generally an hour in a trance; therefore pray consider your honour, for the sake of my love, and let me go, that I may return to you often.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: But will you be sure then to come to morrow night?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Swear.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: By our past kindness.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Well, go your wayes then, if you will, you naughty Creature you. [Ex. Fidel. These young Lovers, with their fears and modesty, make themselves as bad as old ones to us; and I apprehend their bashfulness, more than their tatling.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: O, Madam, we're undone! there was a Gentleman upon the stairs, coming up, with a Candle; which made me retire. Look you, here he comes!

div.stage: Enter Vernish, and his Man with a Light.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: How! my Husband! Oh, undone indeed! This way.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ha! You shall not scape me so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: O Heav'ns! more fears, plagues and torments yet in store!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I guess what your business was here; but this must be your business now. Draw.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: No Expostulations: I shall not care to hear of't. Draw.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: How, you Rascal! not Courage to draw, yet durst do me the greatest injury in the World? Thy Cowardice shall not save thy life.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: O hold, Sir, and send but your Servant down, and I'll satisfie you, Sir, I cou'd not injure you, as you imagine.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Leave the light, and be gone. [Ex. Serv. Now quickly, Sir, what you've to say, or—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I am a Woman, Sir, a very unfortunate Woman.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: How! A very handsom Woman I'm sure then: here are Witnesses of't too, I confess— [Pulls off her Peruke, and feels her breasts. (Well, I'm glad to find the Tables turn'd, my Wife in more danger of Cuckolding, than I was.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Now, Sir, I hope you are so much a Man of Honour, as to let me go, now I have satisfi'd you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: When you have satisfi'd me, Madam, I will.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p:
I hope, Sir, you are too much a Gentleman, to urge those secrets
from a Woman, which concern her Honour: You may guess my misfortune to be Love, by my disguise; but a pair of Breeches cou'd not wrong you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I may believe Love has chang'd your outside, which cou'd not wrong me; but why did my Wife run away?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I know not, Sir; perhaps because she wou'd not be forc'd to discover me to you, or to guide me from your suspitions, that you might not discover me your self: which ungentleman-like curiosity I hope you will cease to have, and let me go.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Well, Madam, if I must not know who you are, 'twill suffice for me only to know certainly what you are: which you must not deny me. Come, there is a Bed within, the proper Rack for Lovers; and if you are a Woman, there you can keep no secrets, you'll tell me there all unask'd. Come.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Oh! what d'ye mean? Help, oh—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I'll show you; but 'tis in vain to cry out: no one dares help you, for I am Lord here.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Tyrant here; but if you are Master of this House, which I have taken for a Sanctuary, do not violate it your self.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: No, I'll preserve you here, and nothing shall hurt you, and will be as true to you, as your disguise; but you must trust me then. Come, come.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Oh! oh! rather than you shall drag me to a death so horrid, and so shameful, I ll die here a thousand deaths: but you do not look like a Ravisher, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Nor you like one wou'd put me to't, but if you will—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Oh! oh! help, help—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: You saucy Rascal, how durst you come in, when you heard a Woman squeak? that shou'd have been your Cue to shut the door.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I come, Sir, to let you know, the Alderman coming home immediately after you were at his house, has sent his Casheer with the money, according to your Note.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Dam his money! money never came to any sure unseasonably, till now. Bid him stay.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He sayes, he cannot a moment.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Receive it you then.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He sayes, he must have your Receit for it: he is in haste, for I hear him coming up, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Dam him. Help me in here then with this dishonorer of my Family.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: You say she is a Woman, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: No matter, Sir: must you prate?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Oh Heav'ns! is there—

div.stage: [They thrust her in, and lock the door.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Stay there, my Prisoner; you have a short Reprieve.

lg.l: I'll fetch the Gold, and that she can't resist;
For with a full hand 'tis we Ravish best.

div.head: ACT. V. Scene I.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: AH, Cousin, nothing troubles me, but that I have given the malicious World its Revenge, and Reason now to talk as freely of me, as I us'd to do of it.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: Faith, then, let not that trouble you; for, to be plain, Cousin, the World cannot talk worse of you, than it did before.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: How, Cousin? I'd have you to know, before this faux pas, this trip of mine, the World cou'd not talk of me.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: Only, that you mind other peoples actions so much, that you take no care of your own, but to hide 'em; that, like a Thief, because you know your self most guilty, you impeach your Fellow Criminals first, to clear your self.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: O wicked World!

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: That you pretend an aversion to all Mankind, in publick, only that their Wives and Mistresses may not be jealous, and hinder you of their conversation, in private.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Base World!

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: That, abroad, you fasten quarrels upon innocent men, for talking of you, only to bring 'em to ask you pardon at home, and to become dear Friends with 'em, who were hardly your acquaintance before.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Abominable World!

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: That you condemn the obscenity of modern Plays, only that you may not be censur'd for never missing the most obscene of the old ones.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Damn'd World!

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: That you deface the nudities of Pictures, and little Statues, only because they are not real.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: O fie, fie, fie; hideous, hideous, Cousin! the obscenity of their Censures makes me blush.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: The truth of 'em, the naughty World wou'd say now.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: O! Madam, here is that Gentleman coming up, who now you say is my Master.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: O! Cousin, whither shall I run? protect me, or—

div.stage: [Olivia runs away, and stands at a distance.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Nay, nay, come—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: O, Sir, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I can forgive you being alone in the dark with a Woman in Mans cloaths; but have a care of a Man in Womans cloaths.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What does he mean? he dissembles, only to get me into his power: Or has my dear Friend made him believe he was a Woman? My Husband may be deceiv'd by him, but I'm sure I was not.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Come, come, you need not have lay'n out of your House for this; but perhaps you were afraid, when I was warm with suspitions, you must have discover'd who she was: And pr'ythee, may I not know it?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: She was— (I hope he has been deceiv'd: and, since my Lover has play'd the Card, I must not renounce.)

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Come, what's the matter with thee? If I must not know who she is, I'm satisfi'd without. Come hither.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Sure you do know her; she has told you her self, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: No, I might have known her better, but that I was interrupted, by the Goldsmith you know, and was forc'd to lock her into your Chamber, to keep her from his sight; but, when I return'd, I found she was got away, by tying the Window-curtains to the Balcony, by which she slid down into the street: for, you must know, I jested with her, and made her believe I'd ravish her; which she apprehended, it seems, in earnest.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Then she got from you?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: And is quite gone?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p:
I'm glad on't— otherwise you had ravish'd her, Sir? but how dar'st you go so far, as to make her believe you wou'd ravish her? let me understand that, Sir. What! there's guilt in your face, you blush
too: nay, then you did ravish her, you did, you base Fellow. What, ravish a Woman in the first Month of our Marriage! 'Tis a double injury to me, thou base ungrateful Man; wrong my Bed already, Villain! I cou'd tear out those false Eyes, barbarous unworthy Wretch.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: So, so!—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Pr'ythee hear, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I will never hear you, my plague, my torment.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I swear— pr'ythee hear me.

sp.speaker: Oliv
sp.p: I have heard already too many of your false Oaths and Vows, especially your last in the Church. O wicked Man! And wretched Woman that I was! I wish I had then sunk down into a Grave, rather than to have given you my hand, to be led to your loathsom Bed. Oh-oh-

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: So, very fine! just a Marriage quarrel! which, tho' it generally begins by the Wives fault, yet, in the conclusion, it becomes the Husbands; and whosoever offends at first, he only is sure to ask pardon at last. My Dear—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: My Devil—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Come, pr'ythee be appeas'd, and go home; I have bespoken our Supper betimes: for I cou'd not eat, till I found you. Go, I'll give you all kind of satisfactions; and one, which uses to be a reconciling one, Two hundred of those Guineys I receiv'd last Night, to do what you will with.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What, wou'd you pay me for being your Baud?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Nay, pr'ythee no more; go, and I'll thoroughly satisfie you, when I come home; and then, too, we will have a fit of laughter, at Manly, whom I am going to find at the Cock in Bow-street, where, I hear, he din'd. Go, dearest, go home.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: A very pretty turn, indeed, this!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Now, Cousin, since by my Wife I have that honour, and priviledge of calling you so, I have something to beg of you too; which is, not to take notice of our Marriage, to any whatever, yet awhile, for some reasons very important to me: and next; that you will do my Wife the honour to go home with her, and me the favour, to use that power you have with her, in our reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: That, I dare promise, Sir, will be no hard matter. Your Servant. [Ex. Vernish. Well, Cousin, this I confess was reasonable hypocrisie; you were the better for't.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What hypocrisie?

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: Why, this last deceit of your Husband was lawful, since in your own defence.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What deceit? I'd have you to know, I never deceiv'd my Husband.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p:
You do not understand me, sure; I say, this was an honest come-off, and a good one: but 'twas a sign your Gallant had had enough of
your conversation, since he cou'd so dextrously cheat your Husband, in passing for a Woman?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What d'ye mean, once more, with my Gallant, and passing for a Woman?

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: What do you mean? You see your Husband took him for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: Hey-day! Why, the Man he found you with, for whom last Night you were so much afraid; and who you told me—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Lord, you rave sure!

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: Why, did not you tell me last night—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I know not what I might tell you last night, in a fright.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: Ay, what was that fright for? for a Woman? besides, were you not afraid to see your Husband just now? I warrant, only for having been found with a Woman! nay, did you not just now too own your false step, or trip, as you call'd it? which was with a Woman too! Fie, this fooling is so insipid, 'tis offensive.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: And fooling with my Honour will be more offensive. Did you not hear my Husband say, he found me with a Woman, in Mans cloaths? And d'ye think he does not know a Man from a Woman?

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: Not so well, I'm sure, as you do; therefore I'd rather take your word.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What, you grow scurrilous, and are I find more censorious, than the World! I must have a care of you, I see.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: No, you need not fear yet, I'll keep your secret.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: My secret! I'd have you to know, I have no need of Confidents, tho' you value your self upon being a good one.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: O admirable confidence! You show more in denying your wickedness, than other people in glorying in't.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Confidence, to me! to me such language! nay, then I'll never see your face again. (I'll quarrel with her, that people may never believe I was in her power; but take for malice all the truth she may speak against me. [Aside.] Lettice, where are you? let us be gone from this censorious, ill Woman.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: Nay, thou shalt stay a little, to damn thy self quite. [Aside. One word first, pray Madam; can you swear that whom your Husband found you with—

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Swear! ay, that whosoever 'twas that stole up, unknown, into my Room, when 'twas dark, I know not whether Man or Woman, by Heav'ns, by all that's good; or, may I never more have joyes here, or in the other World: nay, may I eternally—

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: Be damn'd. So, so, you are damn'd enough already, by your Oaths; and I enough confirm'd: and now you may please to be gone. Yet take this advice with you, in this Plain-dealing Age, to leave off forswearing your self; for when people hardly think the better of a Woman for her real modesty, why shou'd you put that great constraint upon your self to feign it?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: O hideous! hideous advice! Let us go out of the hearing of it: She will spoil us, Lettice.

div.stage: [Ex. Oliv. and Lett. at one door, Eli at t'other.
The Scene changes to the Cock in Bow-street. A Table, and Bottles.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How! sav'd her Honour, by making her Husband believe you were a Woman! 'twas well, but hard enough to do sure.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: We were interrupted, before he cou'd contradict me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But can't you tell me, d'ye say, what kind of man he was?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I was so frightned, I confess, I can give no other account of him, but that he was pretty tall, round fac'd, and one I'm sure I ne'r had seen before.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But she, you say, made you swear to return to night?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: But I have since sworn, never to go near her again; for the Husband wou'd murder me, or worse, if he caught me again.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, I'll go with you, and defend you to night, and then I'll swear too, never to go near her again.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nay, indeed Sir, I will not go, to be accessary to your death too: besides, what shou'd you go again, Sir, for?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No disputing, or advice, Sir; you have reason to know I am unalterable. Go, therefore, presently, and write her a Note to enquire if her assignation with you holds; and if not to be at her own house, where else? and be importunate to gain admittance to her to night: let your Messenger, ere he deliver your Letter, enquire first, if her Husband be gone out. Go, 'tis now almost six of the clock; I expect you back here before seven, with leave to see her then. Go, do this dext'rously, and expect the performance of my last nights promise, never to part with you.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Ay, Sir: but will you be sure to remember that?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Did I ever break my word? go, no more replies, or doubts. [Ex. Fidel. Enter Freeman, to Manly. Where hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: In the next Room, with my Lord Plausible and Novel.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, we came hither, because 'twas a private house; but with thee indeed no house can be private, for thou hast that pretty quality of the familiar Fops of the Town, who, in an eating house, alwayes keep company with all people in't, but those they came with.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
I went into their Room, but to keep them, and my own Fool the
Squire, out of your Room; but you shall be peevish now, because you have no Money: but why the Devil won't you write to those we were speaking of? since your modesty, or your spirit, will not suffer you to speak to 'em, to lend you Money, why won't you try 'em at last, that way?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Because I know 'em already, and can bear Want, better than Denials; nay, than Obligations.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Deny you! they cannot: all of 'em have been your intimate Friends.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, they have been people only I have oblig'd particularly.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Very well; therefore you ought to go to 'em the rather sure.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, no: those you have oblig'd most, most certainly avoid you, when you can oblige 'em no longer; and they take your Visits like so many Duns: Friends, like Mistresses, are avoided, for Obligations past.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Pshaw! but most of 'em are your Relations; Men of great Fortune, and Honour.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes; but Relations have so much Honour, as to think Poverty taints the blood; and disown their wanting Kindred: believing, I suppose, that, as Riches at first makes a Gentleman, the want of 'em degrades him. But, damn 'em, now I'm poor, I'll anticipate their contempt, and disown them.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But you have many a Female acquaintance, whom you have been liberal to, who may have a heart to refund to you a little, if you wou'd ask it: they are not all Olivia's.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Dam thee! how cou'dst thou think of such a thing? I wou'd as soon rob my Footman of his Wages: Besides, 'twere in vain too; for a Wench is like a Box in an Ordinary, receives all peoples Money easily; but there's no getting, nay shaking any out again: and he that fills it, is sure never to keep the Key.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well, but noble Captain, wou'd you make me believe that you, who know half the Town, have so many Friends, and have oblig'd so many, can't borrow fifty or an hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why noble Lieutenant, you who know all the Town, and call all you know Friends, methinks shou'd not wonder at it; since you find Ingratitude too: for how many Lords Families (tho' descended from Blacksmiths, or Tinkers) hast thou call'd Great, and Illustrious? how many ill Tables call good eating? how many noisie Coxcombs, Wits? how many pert Coaching Cowards, stout? how many taudry affected Rogues, well drest? how many Perukes admir'd? and how many ill Verses applauded? and yet canst not borrow a shilling; dost thou expect I, who alwayes spoke truth, shou'd?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, now you think you have paid me; but hark you, Captain, I have heard of a thing call'd grinning Honour, but never of starving Honour.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Well, but it has been the fate of some brave Men: and if they wo' not give me a Ship again, I can go starve any where, with a Musket on my shoulder.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Give you a Ship! why, you will not solicit it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: If I have not solicited it by my services, I know no other way.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir: nay then I'm satisfi'd, I must solicit my Widow the closer, and run the desperate fortune of Matrimony on shore.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How!— Nay, here is a Friend indeed; and he that has him in his arms, can know no wants.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Dear Sir! and he that is in your arms, is secure from all fears whatever; nay, our Nation is secure by your defeat at Sea, and the Dutch that fought against you, have prov'd enemies to themselves only, in bringing you back to us.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Fie, fie; this from a Friend? and yet from any other 'twere unsufferable: I thought I shou'd never have taken any thing ill from you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: A Friends privilege is to speak his mind, tho' it be taken ill.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But your tongue need not tell me you think too well of me; I have found it from your heart, which spoke in actions, your unalterable heart: but Olivia is false, my Friend, which I suppose is no News to you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: He's in the right on't.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But cou'dst thou not keep her true to me?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Not for my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But cou'd you not perceive it at all, before I went? cou'd she so deceive us both?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I must confess, the first time I knew it, was three dayes after your departure, when she receiv'd the Money you had left in Lombard-street, in her name; and her tears did not hinder her it seems from counting that. You wou'd trust her with all, like a true generous Lover!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And she, like a mean Jilting—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Traytrous—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Base—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Damn'd—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Covetous—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Mercenary Whore— (I can hardly hold from laughing)

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, a Mercenary Whore indeed; for she made me pay her, before I lay with her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: How!— Why, have you lay'n with her?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Nay, she deserves you shou'd report it at least, tho' you have not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Report it! by Heav'n, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: How! sure not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I do not use to lie, nor you to doubt me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Last night, about seven or eight of the clock.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ha!— Now I remember, I thought she spake as if she expected some other, rather than me: a confounded Whore indeed!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But, what, thou wonder'st at it! nay, you seem to be angry too.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I cannot but be enrag'd against her, for her usage of you: damn'd, infamous, common Jade.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay, her Cuckold, who first Cuckolded me in my Money, shall not laugh all himself; we will do him reason, shan't we?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But thou dost not, for so great a Friend, take pleasure enough in your Friends Revenge, methinks.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I'm glad to know it, since you have lay'n with her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thou canst not tell me who that Rascal, her Cuckold, is?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: No

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She wou'd keep it from you, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Yes, yes—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Thou wou'dst laugh, if thou knewst but all the circumstances of my having her. Come, I ll tell thee.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Dam her; I care not to hear any more of her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Faith, thou shalt. You must know—

div.stage: Enter Freeman backwards, endeavouring to keep out Novel, Lord Plausible, Jerry and Oldfox, who all press in upon him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I tell you, he has a Wench with him, and wou'd be private.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Dam 'em! a Man can't open a Bottle, in these eating houses, but presently you have these impudent, intruding, buzzing Flies and Insects, in your Glass.— Well, I ll tell thee all anon. In the mean time, pr'ythee go to her, but not from me, and try if you can get her to lend me but an hundred pound of my Money, to supply my present wants; for I suppose there is no recovering any of it by Law.

sp.speaker: Ver
sp.p: Not any; think not of it: nor by this way neither.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Go, try, at least.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I'll go; but I can satisfie you before hand, 'twill be to no purpose: You'll no more find a refunding Wench—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Than a refunding Lawyer; indeed their Fees alike scarce ever return: however, try her, put it to her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I ll try her, put it to her home, with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Nov
sp.p: Nay, you shall be our Judge, Manly. Come, Major, I'll speak it to your teeth: if people provoke me to say bitter things, to their faces, they must take what follows; tho', like my Lord Plausible, I'd rather do't civilly behind their backs.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay, thou art a dangerous Rogue, I've heard, behind a Mans back.

sp.speaker: L. Plaus.
sp.p: You wrong him sure, noble Captain; he wou'd do a Man no more harm behind his back, than to his face.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I am of my Lord's mind.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, a Fool, like a Coward, is the more to be fear'd behind a Man's back, more than a witty Man: for, as a Coward is more bloody than a brave Man, a Fool is more malicious than a Man of Wit..

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: A Fool, Tar— a Fool! nay, thou art a brave Sea-judge of Wit! a Fool! pr'ythee when did you ever find me want something to say, as you do often?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay, I confess, thou art alwayes talking, roaring, or making a noise; that I'll say for thee.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Well, and is talking sign of a Fool?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, alwayes talking; especially too if it be loud and fast, is the sign of a Fool.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Pshaw! Talking is like Fencing, the quicker the better; run 'em down, run 'em down; no matter for parrying; push on still, sa, sa, sa: no matter whether you argue in form, push in guard, or no.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Or hit, or no; I think thou alwayes talk'st without thinking; Novel.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Ay, ay; study'd Play's the worse, to follow the Allegory, as the old Pedant sayes.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: A young Fop!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I ever thought the Man of most Wit, had been, like him of most Money, who has no vanity in shewing it everywhere; whil'st the beggarly pusher of his Fortune, has all he has about him still, only to show.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and makes a very pretty show in the World, let me tell you; nay, a better than your close Hunks: A Pox, give me ready Money in Play; what care I for a Mans reputation? what are we the better for your substantial thrifty Curmudgeon in Wit, Sir?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Thou art a profuse young Rogue indeed.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: So much for talking; which I think I have prov'd a mark of Wit; and so is Railing, Roaring, and making a noise: for, Railing is Satyr, you know; and Roaring, and making a noise, Humor.

div.stage: Enter to them, Fidelia, taking Manly aside, and shewing him a paper.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: The hour is betwixt seven and eight exactly: 'tis now half an hour after six.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Well, go then to the Piazza, and wait for me; as soon as it is quite dark, I'll be with you: I must stay here yet a while, for my Friend. But is Railing Satyr, Novel?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And Roaring, and making a noise, Humor?

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: What, won't you confess there's Humor in Roaring, and making a noise?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Nor in cutting Napkins, and Hangings?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, sure.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Dull Fops!

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: O Rogue, Rogue, insipid Rogue! Nay, Gentlemen, allow him those things for Wit; for his parts lie only that way.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Peace, old Fool, I wonder not at thee; but that young Fellows shou'd be so dull, as to say, there's no Humor in making a noise, and breaking Windows! I tell you, there's Wit and Humor too, in both: And a Wit is as well known by his Frolick, as by his Simile.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Pure Rogue! there's your modern Wit for you! Wit, and Humor, in breaking of Windows! There's Mischief, if you will; but no Wit, or Humor.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Pry'thee, pr'ythee peace, old Fool. I tell you, where there is Mischief, there's Wit. Don't we esteem the Monky a Wit amongst Beasts, only because he's mischievous? And let me tell you, as good Nature is a sign of a Fool, being Mischievous is a sign of Wit..

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: O Rogue, Rogue! pretend to be a Wit, by doing Mischief and Railing!

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Why, thou, old Fool, hast no other pretence to the name of a Wit, but by Railing at new Playes.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Thou, by Railing at that facetious, noble way of Wit, quibling.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Thou call'st thy dulness, gravity; and thy dozing, thinking.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: You, Sir, your dulness, spleen: And you talk much, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Thou read'st much, and understand'st nothing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: You laugh loud, and break no Jest.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: You rail, and no body hangs himself: And thou hast nothing of the Satyr, but in thy face.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: And you have no jest, but your face, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Thou art an illiterate Pedant.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Thou art a Fool, with a bad Memory.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Come, a Pox on you both, you have done like Wits now;
for you Wits, when you quarrel, never give over, till you prove one another Fools.

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: And you Fools have never any occasion of laughing at us Wits, but when we quarrel: therefore, let us be Friends, Oldfox.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They are such Wits as thou art, who make the name of a Wit as scandalous, as that of Bully; and signifie a loud-laughing, talking, incorrigible Coxcomb; as Bully, a roaring, hardned Coward.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And wou'd have his noise and laughter pass for Wit; as t'other his huffing and blustring, for Courage.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Gentlemen, with your leave, here is one I wou'd speak with, and I have nothing to say to you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I told you 'twas in vain, to think of getting Money out of her: she sayes, if a shilling wou'd do't, she wou'd not save you from starving, or hanging, or what you wou'd think worse, begging or flattering; and rails so at you, one wou'd not think you had lay'n with her,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: O, Friend, never trust, for that matter, a Womans railing; for she is no less a dissembler in her hatred, than her love: And as her fondness of her Husband is a sign he's a Cuckold, her railing at another Man is a sign she lies with him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: He's in the right on't: I know not what to trust to.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But you did not take any notice of it to her, I hope?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: So!— Sure he is afraid I shou'd have disprov'd him, by an enquiry of her: all may be well yet.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What hast thou in thy head, that makes thee seem so unquiet?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Only this base, impudent Womans falsness: I cannot put her out of my head.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: O my dear Friend, be not you too sensible of my wrongs, for then I shall feel 'em too, with more pain, and think 'em unsufferable. Dam her, her Money, and that ill-natur'd Whore too, Fortune her self; but if thou wou'dst ease a little my present trouble, pr'ythee go borrow me somewhere else, some Money: I can trouble thee.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: You trouble me indeed, most sensibly, when you command me any thing I cannot do: I have lately lost a great deal of Money at Play, more than I can yet pay; so that not only my Money, but my Credit too is gone, and know not where to borrow; but cou'd rob a Church for you. (Yet wou'd rather end your wants, by cutting your throat.)

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Nay, then I doubly feel my poverty, since I'm incapable of supplying
thee.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: But, methinks, she that granted you the last favour, (as they call it) shou'd not deny you any thing—

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Hey, Tarpaulin, have you done?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I understand not that point of kindness, I confess.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, thou dost not understand it, and I have not time to let you know all now, for these Fools, you see, will interrupt us; but anon, at Supper, we'll laugh at leisure together, at Olivia's Cuckold; who took a young Fellow, that goes between his Wife and me, for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sensless, easie Rascal! 'twas no wonder she chose him for a Husband; but she thought him, I thank her, fittter than me, for that blind, bearing Office.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I cou'd not be deceiv'd in that long Womans hair ty'd up behind; nor those infallible proofs, her pouting, swelling breasts: I have handled too many sure not to know 'em.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What, you wonder the Fellow cou'd be such a blind Coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Yes, yes—

sp.speaker: Nov.
sp.p: Nay, pr'ythee come to us, Manly; Gad, all the fine things one sayes, in their company, are lost, without thee.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Away, Fop; I'm busie yet. You see we cannot talk here at our ease; besides, I must be gone immediately, in order to meeting with Olivia again to night.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: To night! it cannot be sure—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I had an appointment just now from her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: For what time?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: At half an hour after seven precisely.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Don't you apprehend the Husband?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He! sniveling Gull! he a thing to be fear'd! a Husband, the tamest of creatures!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Very fine!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But, pr'ythee, in the mean time, go try to get me some Money. Tho' thou art too modest to borrow for thy self, thou canst do any thing for me I know. Go; for I must be gone to Olivia: go, and meet me here anon.— Freeman, where are you!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
Ay, I'll meet with you, I warrant; but it shall be at Olivia's. Sure it cannot be; she denies it so calmly, and with that honest, modest assurance, it can't be true— and he does not use to lye— but belying a Woman, when she won't be kind, is the onely lye a brave Man will least scruple. But then the Woman in Mans cloaths, whom he calls a Man!-
Well, but, by her Breasts, I know her to be a Woman:— But then, again, his appointment from her, to meet with him to night! I am distracted more with doubt, than jealousie. Well, I have no way to disabuse or revenge my self, but by going home immediately, putting on a riding Sute, and pretending to my Wife the same business which carry'd me out of Town last, requires me again to go Post to Oxford to night; then, if the appointment he boasts of be true, it's sure to hold; and I shall have an opportunity either of clearing her, or revenging my self on both. Perhaps, she is his Wench, of an old date, and I am his Cully, whil'st I think him mine; and he has seem'd to make his Wench rich, only that I might take her off of his hands: or if he has but lately lay'n with her, he must needs discover, by her, my treachery to him; which I'm sure he will revenge with my death, and which I must prevent with his, if it were only but for fear of his too just reproaches; for, I must confess, I never had till now any excuse, but that of int'rest, for doing ill to him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Come hither, only I say be sure you mistake not the time; you know the house exactly where Olivia lodges: 'tis just hard by.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Well then, bring 'em all, I say, thither, and all you know that may be then in the house; for the more Witnesses I have of her infamy, the greater will be my revenge: and be sure you come strait up to her Chamber, without more ado. Here, take the Watch: you see 'tis above a quarter past seven; be there in half an hour exactly.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You need not doubt my diligence, or dexterity; I am an old Scowrer, and can naturally beat up a Wenches quarters that won't be civil. Sha'nt we break her Windows too?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, no: be punctual only.

div.stage: Enter Widow Blackacre, and two Knights of the Post: a Waiter with Wine.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sweetheart, are you sure the door was shut close, that none of those Roysters saw us come in?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Yes, Mistriss; and you shall have a privater Room above, instantly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are safe enough, Gentlemen, for I have been private in this house ere now, upon other occasions, when I was something younger. Come, Gentlemen, in short, I leave my business to your care and fidelity: and so, here's to you.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight.
sp.p:
We were ungrateful Rogues, if we shou'd not be honest
to you; for we have had a great deal of your Money.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And you have done me many a good job for't: and so, here's to you again.

sp.speaker: 2. Knight.
sp.p: Why, we have been perjur'd, but six times for you.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight.
sp.p: Forg'd but four Deeds, with your Husband's last Deed of Gift.

sp.speaker: 2. Knight.
sp.p: And but three Wills.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight.
sp.p: And counterfeited Hands and Seals to some six Bonds; I think that's all, Brother.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ay, that's all, Gentlemen; and so, here's to you again.

sp.speaker: 2. Knight.
sp.p: Nay, 'twou'd do one's heart good to be forsworn for you: you have a conscience in your wayes, and pay us well.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight.
sp.p: You are in the right on't, Brother; one wou'd be damn'd for her, with all ones heart.

sp.speaker: 2. Knight.
sp.p: But there are Rogues, who make us forsworn for 'em; and when we come to be paid, they'll be forsworn too, and not pay us our wages which they promis'd with Oaths sufficient.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight.
sp.p: Ay, a great Lawyer, that shall be nameless Bilkt me too.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That was hard, methinks, that a Lawyer shou'd use Gentlemen Witnesses no better.

sp.speaker: 2. Knight.
sp.p: A Lawyer! d'ye wonder a Lawyer shou'd do't? I was Bilk'd by a Reverend Divine, that preaches twice on Sundayes, and prayes half an hour still before dinner.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How? a Conscientious Divine, and not pay people for damning themselves! Sure then, for all his talking, he does not believe damnation. But come, to our business: pray be sure to imitate exactly the flourish at the end of this name.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight.
sp.p: O he's the best in England at untangling a flourish, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And let not the Seal be a jot bigger: observe well the dash too, at the end of this name.

sp.speaker: 2. Knight.
sp.p: I warrant you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well, these, and many other shifts, poor Widows are put to sometimes; for every body wou'd be riding a Widow, as they say, and breaking into her Jointure: they think marrying a Widow an easie business, like leaping the Hedge, where another has gone over before; a Widow is a meer gap, a gap with them. Enter to them Major Oldfox, with two Waiters. [The Knights of the Post huddle up the Writings. What, he here! go then, go, my hearts, you have your instructions.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Come, Madam, to be plain with you, I'll be fob'd off no longer. I'll bind her and gag her, but she shall hear me. [Aside. Look you, Friends, there's the Money I promis'd you; and now do you
what you promis'd me: here are my Garters, and here's a Gag: you shall be acquainted with my parts, Lady, you shall.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Acquainted with your parts! A Rape, a Rape— What, will you ravish me?

div.stage: [The Waiters tye her to the Chair, and gag her; and Ex.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Yes, Lady, I will ravish you; but it shall be through the ear, Lady, the ear onely, with my well-pen'd Acrostics. Enter to-them, Freeman, Jerry Blackacre, three Bayliffs, a Constable and his Assistants, with the two Knights of the Post. What, shall I never read my things undisturb'd again?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: O Law! my Mother bound hand and foot, and gaping, as if she rose before her time to day!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What means this, Oldfox? But I'll release you from him: you shall be no Mans Prisoner, but mine. Bayliffs, execute your Writ.

sp.speaker: Old
sp.p: Nay, then I'll be gone, for fear of being Bayl, and paying her Debts, without being her Husband.

sp.speaker: 1. Bay.
sp.p: We Arrest you, in the King's Name, at the Suit of Mr. Freeman, Guardian to Ieremiah Blackacre Esq in an Action of Ten thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How! how! in a Choak-Bayl Action! What, and the Pen and Ink Gentlemen taken too! Have you confest, you Rogues?

sp.speaker: 1. Knight.
sp.p: We needed not to confess; for the Bayliffs dog'd us hither to the very door, and overheard all that you and we said

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Undone, undone then! no Man was ever too hard for me, till now. O, Ierry, Child, wilt thou vex again the womb that bore thee?

sp.speaker: Ierr.
sp.p: Ay, for bearing me before Wedlock, as you say: But I'll teach you to call a Blackacre a Bastard, tho' you were never so much my Mother.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well, I'm undone: not one trick left? no Law-Meush imaginable? [Aside. Cruel Sir, a word with you I pray.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: In vain, Madam; for you have no other way to release your self, but by the Londs of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How, Sir, how! that were but to sue out an Habeas Corpus, for a removal from one Prison to another. Matrimony!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well, Bayliffs, away with her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
O stay, Sir, can you be so cruel as to bring me under Covert Baron again? and put it out of my power to sue in my own name. Matrimony, to a Woman, worse than Excommunication, in depriving her of the benefit of the Law: and I wou'd rather be depriv'd of life. But hark you, Sir, I am contented you shou'd hold and enjoy my person by Lease or Patent; but not by the spiritual Patent, call'd a Licence; that
